Narrator: *Mizora channelled the Hells' essence into you - you'll never be rid of their scent.*

Counsellor Florrick: Wyll? What has become of you?
InternalNodeContext: Player inside the cell
Player: Calm down, this cell was trivial to unlock. Getting out of here will be easy.
Counsellor Florrick: You don't get it. We lost.
Counsellor Florrick: I came seeking allies to our cause. Watchers spotted me, dragged me to Ulder Ravengard's husk.
Counsellor Florrick: Empty as a stare. Your father's a tadpole's puppet, Wyll. Nothing more.
Counsellor Florrick: Empty as a stare. A tadpole's puppet, nothing more.
Counsellor Florrick: He spoke in accusations. Apostasy, conspiracy, sedition.
Counsellor Florrick: I will soon be hanged on the city gallows to a chorus of cheers.
Counsellor Florrick: You might have unlocked my cell, but there's no escape from this place.
Wyll: The Hells with that. Nothing is over. Not while I still draw breath.
Player: I found your duke. He's dead, I'm sorry to say.
Counsellor Florrick: He's - dead? So perishes the city. I can - I can scarcely bear it.
Counsellor Florrick: Forget it. Baldur's Gate's good as cinder. An illithid hive beyond saving.
: True
Narrator: *You recall the tales of Gorion's Ward, the great hero of Baldur's Gate. Without them, the city would have succumbed to war, famine, and worse.*
Player: Coward. Balduran didn't build the Gate for you to weep as it burns.
: True
Player: Gorion's Ward overcame great odds to protect the city. You can do the same.
Counsellor Florrick: 'When the people need a miracle, you cannot wait for the gods to answer.' Ulder's words. I'd almost forgotten.
Counsellor Florrick: No more sulking. I know what to do.
Counsellor Florrick: Unlock my cell, escort me out of Wyrm's Rock.
Counsellor Florrick: I'll seek out my connections. When the city's streets shatter, you'll want their blades.
Player: I won't help you.

GROUP_SteelWatchers: Stand down, villain. In the name of the Steel Watch.
GROUP_SteelWatchers: Aggressive action will not be tolerated in the presence of the patriars of this proud city.
Player: Point taken. I'll keep things peaceful.
GROUP_SteelWatchers: The Steel Watch appreciate your cooperation, citizen.
NodeContext: Gets new command after starting to engage. Gortash sends a remote command to let the player through.
Lord Enver Gortash: Dearest patriars, but a moment. I must greet a most honoured guest.
NodeContext: Magninamously and a bir formal, but still in the style of a politician where you can't tell if he's being sarcastic
Lord Enver Gortash: Crawling back from their bloody disgrace - it's my favourite assassin! Gods, you're a sight for sore eyes.
Lord Enver Gortash: Orin told me she made a fool of you, but I should've known you wouldn't go down that easy.
Player: I like your tone! But humour me: I have amnesia.
Lord Enver Gortash: Then she didn't lie - the past is lost to you. Let me clear up some mysteries, then. We share so much history.
Lord Enver Gortash: You and I initiated this plot. We discussed in depth the failures of our predecessors and how to avoid them.
Lord Enver Gortash: We understood that if we were to unite, no one could stand in the way of the Dead Three.
Lord Enver Gortash: So unite we did. First we obtained the crown; then we enslaved the brain. From there, it was but a small step to the most successful religious hoax ever perpetrated.
Player: What was my role in this plan?
Lord Enver Gortash: In Bhaal's name, you set your bloody daggers to cause panic in the streets, killing in the Absolute's name.
Lord Enver Gortash: You would have carried out that part of the plan, had Orin not ruined your hard work.
Lord Enver Gortash: Next, the threat of the Absolute's monstrous armies formed by Myrkul's general, Ketheric Thorm.
Lord Enver Gortash: In such circumstances, people crave strong leaders. Leaders that bring law, order, and protection. Leaders like me, Bane's unyielding hand, author of justice.
Lord Enver Gortash: You are soon to witness the people of Baldur's Gate granting me complete power over them. All out of fear of the Absolute.
Lord Enver Gortash: Next, I - we - will declare curfew and begin infecting the masses. Our subjects will hear the voice of their Absolute god.
Lord Enver Gortash: The faithful will do anything in the name of their god.
Player: I've heard enough. Am I free to go?
Lord Enver Gortash: Soon. First, come and be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate.
Lord Enver Gortash: Now come, be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate.
Player: I wouldn't dream of missing it.
Lord Enver Gortash: Then we proceed. The patriars await.
Lord Enver Gortash: Distinguished dukes, patriars. Dearest Ravengard - I will heed your call. A new chapter begins.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gortash approaches Ravengard. Ravengard nods and steps forward. He holds a sword aloft - the sword of Balduran, perhaps. Gortash kneels, back to player. Everyone takes position for the Archduke ceremony.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Enver Gortash. Swearest thou, by Balduran's blade, to defend the citizens of Baldur's Gate from enemies within and without?
Lord Enver Gortash: I swear.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Swearest thou true faith and fealty to the same, by word, deed, and decree, so that none may suffer?
Lord Enver Gortash: I swear.
NodeContext: Gortadsh is still kneeling looking down.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Gathered guests, grant ye consent?
Player: Prepare to object.
GROUP_Emperors: Don't. You'll only invite his ire. And your own death.
Player: Stop this. Gortash and Ravengard are with the Absolute!
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A traitor's words - they mean to fracture this Council!
Lord Enver Gortash: Patriars - let it be known. The War of the Absolute has begun.

Nightwarden Minthara: I do not have time for interruptions from underlings.
Narrator: *As she turns to you, her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
NodeContext: unnerved
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player sees a vision of Minthara with Orin, one of the Absolute's chosen.
InternalNodeContext: Cinematic blocked until Orin asset/voice available.
InternalNodeContext: Cinematic blocked until Orin asset/voice available.
Nightwarden Minthara: A True Soul? Praise be, sister. Are you here to join my hunt?
Nightwarden Minthara: Her heart is more generous than mine. Join my hunt, faerie. And obey me.
Player: I'm on a hunt of my own. I'm looking for a druid named Halsin.
Nightwarden Minthara: Interesting. What do you know of this druid?
Player: I visited his grove.
Nightwarden Minthara: Perfect. This grove is the place I am seeking. Show me where it is, and we will destroy it together.
Nightwarden Minthara: There is a weapon the Absolute seeks - I'm sure those wretches have it hidden away there. We will find it, amongst the dead and the ashes.
Narrator: *Her excitement is palpable. She lingers on thoughts of victory, of unbelievers' blood spilled...*
Narrator: *...and of the weapon. She will seize it, in the Absolute's name.*
Narrator: *You feel Shadowheart's anxiety. The weapon the Absolute seeks - it's the artefact that she carries. The same one that protected you as you entered the goblin camp.*
Narrator: *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.*
Narrator: *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*
Player: The grove's inhabitants are weak - it's ready to fall.
Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin.
Nightwarden Minthara: Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.*
Narrator: *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Allow her to read your thoughts.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...*
Narrator: *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect.
Nightwarden Minthara: If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: And once I'm inside?
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: Reject these dreams of a bloodbath.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: If I do this, I expect to be rewarded.

Mizora: One taste, one indulgence - but the delicious agony remains. A pity for you the one taste is all I'll give.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: From earth do we rise. In fire are we forged. In steel are we mighty!
NodeContext: The end of a rousing speech.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Lord Enver Gortash, the people cry your name. Will you -
Narrator: *For the briefest moment, you are one with Duke Ravengard. His mind is void - a vessel of the Absolute, awaiting command.*
Wyll: Father...
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My Lord. We have a guest.
Lord Enver Gortash: Exquisite timing. Dearest patriars, but a moment. Lord Enver Gortash at your service.
Lord Enver Gortash: Karlach! My dear, aren't you a sight for sore eyes. How long has it been? Five years? Six? I'm delighted to see you again.
Lord Enver Gortash: Lord Enver Gortash at your service.
Lord Enver Gortash: And you are: a marvel. You've brought Ketheric to his knees and made Orin grovel.
Lord Enver Gortash: My master knows you - for who you are, and for the Netherstones that you carry.
Lord Enver Gortash: Oh, yes - we've much to discuss. But first, come and be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate.
Player: Fine. Let's get this sham coronation over with.
Lord Enver Gortash: You will follow me. And you will show due respect.

Sceleritas Fel: Master. You are the chosen one.
NodeContext: Awestruck
Sceleritas Fel: He is near... He comes for you.
NodeContext: Butler's body beginning to vibrate, and jerk strangely
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The butler levitates, held up in the air like a broken marionette on invisible strings. Daggers manifest in the air around him and plunge into his body, making a gory pincusion of him. His mutilated corpse crashes to the ground, and the blood that runs from it forms a dark pool.

A light glows within the pool, and within the reflection, we see the Bhaal Temple - the eyes of the skull light with flame within the reflection, and a figure moves out of the darkness toward the surface of the pool, where it connects to reality. It is the butler, his hat gone, the flesh peeled back from his skull in places. Thoroughly mutilated and disfigured. His eyes burn with unholy fire - he has become an Avatar of Bhaal.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: Let's not let an ancient squabble interfere with the task at hand.
Isobel: Not as ancient as you think.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I'm glad you've remembered who needs whose help here.
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I am already protected. My Lady shields me from the curse.
Isobel: For now, perhaps. But Shar can be fickle, and her love can prove fleeting. Do not turn your back on an advantage you may need... even a Selnite one.
Isobel: If nothing else, it can aid any companions who travel with you - somehow I doubt Shar's largesse was extended to them.
Player: It was nothing. Put it out of your mind.
Narrator: *But was it truly nothing? The pain gripped you tight, robbing you of all composure for a moment...*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we?
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Narrator: *You are enveloped in myriad sensations, all at once. Flaming desire and icy despair; the strength of iron and the haze of thick swamp mist.*
Mizora: The Nine Hells of Baator. The ultimate torment, some souls would say.
Mizora: Tsk. Those souls lack imagination.
Player: Show me more.
Mizora: With pleasure. As long as you're willing to give in.
Mizora: A banquet lies before you. Why should you not gorge?
Player: Give in to the infernal sensations.
Mizora: I'm going to show you the true wages of your sin.
Narrator: *Pure lust courses through your veins and plucks at your flesh. You don't know what you want, only that you want it.*
Mizora: You feel it, don't you? Primal hunger, irrepressible decadence. Forget the heavens - this is paradise.
Mizora: Let me show you.
Player: Sigh and brace yourself.
Mizora: What's the matter. Don't you trust me?
Narrator: *An inferno engulfs you. Your lust blazes hot.*
Mizora: Do you feel it? Avernus. Where Hells' legions march, screaming their rage. Where the Styx collects the blood of the fallen.
Mizora: Where your rightful mistress shoulders the burdens of perpetual war.
Mizora: Reach out. Have a taste.
Player: Give it to me.
Narrator: *The flavour is exquisite as spiced wine, terrible as rotting offal. It does not quench your lust - it only stokes it.*

The player makes a fist, the flame extinguishes, but in doing so a new flood of sensation rushes into their core. Their back and neck arch slightly as they breath deep.
Mizora: Don't worry, pet. I won't leave 'til you're fully satisfied.
Mizora: Dis, the blackened elysium. Minauros, the rotting bog. The molten seas and soil of Phlegethos. Stygia, the frozen ocean.
Mizora: Choose a Hell. Have your fill.
Player: The icy seas of Stygia.
Narrator: *You are immersed in a cold ocean blanketed by twilight. Lightning strikes you, energising and illuminating. Now that you know the thrill of its shock, you yearn for more.*

The player extends both arms out toward the flames, palms down. Their eyes close as they connect with Mizora's hellish offerings.

She watches as the pleasure rides out the sensations.

NodeContext: Magninamously and a bir formal, but still in the style of a politician where you can't tell if he's being sarcastic
Lord Enver Gortash: My friend - forgive the cold welcome. My Steel Watchers are eager watchdogs. For the good of the people, I'm sure you understand.
NodeContext: Politician through and through. Charismatic enough to understand how he's so popular. Sllimy enough for his bad faith to shine through,
Lord Enver Gortash: But - my stars! That can't be my old friend Karlach, can it? How long has it been? Five years? Six? I'm delighted to see you again.
Lord Enver Gortash: Lord Enver Gortash at your service.
Lord Enver Gortash: I understand congratulations are in order. Thorm's defeat hasn't gone unnoticed. You're known - for who you are, and for that Netherstone that you carry.
Lord Enver Gortash: Ah - and my old friend Karlach. It's no wonder your victory was so decisive. It's lovely to see you again, darling.
Karlach: I'm sure it is.
Lord Enver Gortash: We'll catch up once we've covered more pressing matters - Thorm's Netherstone, more to the point.
Lord Enver Gortash: I knew I'd meet Ketheric's slayer eventually, but I had no idea it was you, Karlach.
Player: Speak your piece, Gortash.
Lord Enver Gortash: You have Thorm's Netherstone. We must discuss what that means.
Lord Enver Gortash: You know, it takes all three to control the brain. Without Thorm's, it's become vexingly wilful.
Lord Enver Gortash: The quakes are a clear warning. If nobody steps in soon, it'll free itself from the authority of the crown.
Lord Enver Gortash: I expect it'll start with turning the Sword Coast's infected - you among them. That Prism of yours won't last indefinitely.
Lord Enver Gortash: Next, the Grand Design. The mind flayer empire reborn. If we're lucky, we'll become slaves. If we're unlucky, well -
Lord Enver Gortash: Not the most thrilling of prospects. But it's a fate that can be avoided if you and I come to an understanding.
Lord Enver Gortash: You may have wrought the destruction of my Iron Throne, brought my Steel Watch to its knees - but that's how I know you'd make a most formidable ally.
Lord Enver Gortash: Together we can still restore authority over the brain.

Player: I am ending this here, consequences be damned.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: You can tell my allegiance from a look?
Isobel: It's an aura. Or a lack of one, really.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: You seem to have a lot to say about my allegiance. Can we focus on the task at hand?
Isobel: I suppose that would be wise. We have a common enemy, after all: Ketheric Thorm.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Player: It was nothing. Put it out of your mind.
Narrator: *But was it truly nothing? The pain gripped you tight, robbing you of all composure for a moment...*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we?
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Narrator: *This is the one Sceleritas sent you to kill. Every scrap of your marrow yearns to end her.*

Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*

GROUP_SteelWatchers: Stand down, villain. In the name of the Steel Watch.
GROUP_SteelWatchers: Aggressive action will not be tolerated in the presence of the patriars of this proud city.

NodeContext: Gets new command after starting to engage. Gortash sends a remote command to let the player through.
Lord Enver Gortash: Dearest patriars, but a moment. I must greet a most honoured guest.
NodeContext: Magninamously and a bir formal, but still in the style of a politician where you can't tell if he's being sarcastic
Lord Enver Gortash: Crawling back from their bloody disgrace - it's my favourite assassin! Gods, you're a sight for sore eyes.
Lord Enver Gortash: Orin told me she made a fool of you, but I should've known you wouldn't go down that easy.
Player: I have no clue what you're talking about - my memories are blighted.
Lord Enver Gortash: Then she didn't lie - the past is lost to you. Let me clear up some mysteries, then. We share so much history.
Lord Enver Gortash: You and I initiated this plot. We discussed in depth the failures of our predecessors and how to avoid them.
Lord Enver Gortash: We understood that if we were to unite, no one could stand in the way of the Dead Three.
Lord Enver Gortash: So unite we did. First we obtained the crown; then we enslaved the brain. From there, it was but a small step to the most successful religious hoax ever perpetrated.
Player: Ask the Emperor: Is he telling the truth?
GROUP_Emperors: It seems so.
Player: What was my role in this plan?
Lord Enver Gortash: In Bhaal's name, you set your bloody daggers to cause panic in the streets, killing in the Absolute's name.
Lord Enver Gortash: You would have carried out that part of the plan, had Orin not ruined your hard work.
Lord Enver Gortash: Next, the threat of the Absolute's monstrous armies formed by Myrkul's general, Ketheric Thorm.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: I thought I smelled a Selnite.
Isobel: At your service.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I may have the parasite of a True Soul, but not the mind of one.
Isobel: And that's what makes you essential.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Narrator: *Pain bursts from the wound on your hand. You see yourself kneeling in a dark hall, surrounded by initiates. A female voice preaches against Selne and all she stands for. You nod, rapt.*
InternalNodeContext: Incurable wound imagery/memoriy fragment
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: I don't know what to make of it myself.
Isobel: I suppose Shar is nothing if not mysterious.
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows whats inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I don't know.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: How did you come to study mind flayer parasites?
Halsin: A drow forced me to defend myself. Afterwards, I was able to study the parasite that slithered out of the corpse, see what drives these 'True Souls'.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: The other druids are dead, by my hand.
Halsin: What...? How? Why?! Explain yourself at once!
Player: They left me no choice. I had to defend myself.
Halsin: Then... then it is as you say. They forgot their principles; you had no choice. I will mourn them when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You are aware you're asking me to kill a drow?
Halsin: You drow relish turning on your own, if there's something to be gained. Don't pretend otherwise.
Player: Not all drow are as you say.
Halsin: Unfair of me, perhaps, but I've had few encounters with drow to make me think otherwise.
Halsin: Perhaps you can enlighten me.
Player: You ask too much of me. I can't help you.

Wyll: I was such a godsdamned fool. I believed in you. I believed in us.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows whats inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I escaped from an illithid ship after being infected. Maybe the process was interrupted.
Halsin: Perhaps... but I wouldn't want to place all my faith in blind luck.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: You learned all this from your studies?
Halsin: Indeed. After we dealt with the drow that ambushed us, Nettie and I were able to inspect the corpse - and the creature that slithered out of it.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: All right. How do I help?
Halsin: My thanks. If you prevail, I'll owe you the debt of a lifetime.
Halsin: Rare is the beast that survives decapitation. Help me eliminate the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: The grove isn't my problem. I have to concentrate on saving myself.

Wyll: It's funny.
Wyll: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.
Wyll: I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army.
Wyll: But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The poignant tedium of your story?
Wyll: I'd like to think not. The answer is much simpler than that:
Wyll: Time.
Wyll: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. My eternal soul is at its mercy.
Wyll: It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods.
Wyll: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.
Wyll: It even comes for your people in the astral sea. Time may hunt slowly - but it still hunts.
Wyll: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop it -
Wyll: If just for a moment.
Wyll: Come, let me show you.
Player: Go on - I'll follow.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright. NOTE: Karlach CANNOT take Wyll's hand, they shouldn't be touching.See N41
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.
Wyll: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.
Wyll: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.
Wyll: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: Seriously? You dragged me out here to look at a tree?
Wyll: I did. But also to see something else:
Wyll: Me.
Wyll: I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before -
Wyll: And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic.
Wyll: If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight:
Wyll: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: Gods, no. Have you looked at yourself? You're hideous.

Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: Isobel - Isobel Thorm?
: True
Narrator: *Her breath catches; you notice a barely-perceptible shudder run through her body.*
Isobel: An unfortunate coincidence. I hope never to meet the wicked man who haemorrhaged shadows over this peaceful village. I've heard you might be the person to stop him.
Isobel: A True Soul with a soul. Imagine.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I'm glad you've remembered who needs whose help here.
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Player: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: I don't know what to make of it myself.
Isobel: I suppose Shar is nothing if not mysterious.
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.

Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows whats inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I don't know.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: So all of this was for nothing.
Halsin: Patience. I can't just snap my fingers... but I know where the solution almost certainly lies.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha is dead. She was swayed by Shadow Druids. I had no choice.
Halsin: Kagha... This is my fault - I was her teacher. I will mourn her when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You ask too much of me. I can't help you.

Wyll: It's funny.
Wyll: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.
Wyll: I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army.
Wyll: But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The poignant tedium of your story?
Wyll: I'd like to think not. The answer is much simpler than that:
Wyll: Time.
Wyll: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. My eternal soul is at its mercy.
Wyll: It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods.
Wyll: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.
Wyll: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop time -
Wyll: If just for a moment.
Wyll: Come, let me show you.
Player: Go on - I'll follow.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright. NOTE: Karlach CANNOT take Wyll's hand, they shouldn't be touching.See N41
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.
Wyll: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.
Wyll: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.
Wyll: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: Enjoy the view. Enjoy Wyll's quiet company.
Wyll: I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before -
Wyll: And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic.
Wyll: If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight:
Wyll: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: Gods, no. Have you looked at yourself? You're hideous.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player sits on the ground with the camera directly facing them. Mizora stands behind the player, her wings open wide.
NOTE: Player sits in Jeff Goldblum languid pose.

Mizora: And you - not a mark on you. You burn just as hot as myself, dear sister.
Narrator: *Your pores flood with heat and frigid water. Your parched tongue searches for the right response.*
Player: This was a mistake. Nothing more. I'm disgusted with myself.
Mizora: Tsk. You're a terrible liar. Your time in Avernus taught you nothing.
Mizora: One taste, one indulgence - but the delicious agony remains. A pity for you the one taste is all I'll give.

Wyll: Countless souls walk these planes, countless ways to find pleasure. And out of all of them, you chose her.
Wyll: Do you understand what she did - what you did?
Player: It's not what you think it is, I swear.
Wyll: Mm-hmm.
Player: Yes. I shared a night of ecstasy with the hottest devil this side of Avernus.

GROUP_SteelWatchers: Stand down, villain. In the name of the Steel Watch.
GROUP_SteelWatchers: Aggressive action will not be tolerated in the presence of the patriars of this proud city.
Player: Point taken. I'll keep things peaceful.
GROUP_SteelWatchers: The Steel Watch appreciate your cooperation, citizen.
NodeContext: Gets new command after starting to engage. Gortash sends a remote command to let the player through.
Lord Enver Gortash: Dearest patriars, but a moment. I must greet a most honoured guest.
NodeContext: Magninamously and a bir formal, but still in the style of a politician where you can't tell if he's being sarcastic
Lord Enver Gortash: Crawling back from their bloody disgrace - it's my favourite assassin! Gods, you're a sight for sore eyes.
Lord Enver Gortash: Orin told me she made a fool of you, but I should've known you wouldn't go down that easy.
Player: You know me?
Lord Enver Gortash: Then she didn't lie - the past is lost to you. Let me clear up some mysteries, then. We share so much history.
Lord Enver Gortash: You and I initiated this plot. We discussed in depth the failures of our predecessors and how to avoid them.
Lord Enver Gortash: We understood that if we were to unite, no one could stand in the way of the Dead Three.
Lord Enver Gortash: So unite we did. First we obtained the crown; then we enslaved the brain. From there, it was but a small step to the most successful religious hoax ever perpetrated.
Player: What was my role in this plan?
Lord Enver Gortash: In Bhaal's name, you set your bloody daggers to cause panic in the streets, killing in the Absolute's name.
Lord Enver Gortash: You would have carried out that part of the plan, had Orin not ruined your hard work.
Lord Enver Gortash: Next, the threat of the Absolute's monstrous armies formed by Myrkul's general, Ketheric Thorm.
Lord Enver Gortash: In such circumstances, people crave strong leaders. Leaders that bring law, order, and protection. Leaders like me, Bane's unyielding hand, author of justice.
Lord Enver Gortash: You are soon to witness the people of Baldur's Gate granting me complete power over them. All out of fear of the Absolute.
Lord Enver Gortash: Next, I - we - will declare curfew and begin infecting the masses. Our subjects will hear the voice of their Absolute god.
Lord Enver Gortash: The faithful will do anything in the name of their god.
Player: Very clever.
Lord Enver Gortash: More importantly, just.
Lord Enver Gortash: Now come, be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate.
Player: I have no interest in this sham of a ceremony.
Lord Enver Gortash: This is the first step towards our glory. I really must insist.
Lord Enver Gortash: You will follow me. And you will show due respect.
Lord Enver Gortash: Distinguished dukes, patriars. Dearest Ravengard - I will heed your call. A new chapter begins.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gortash approaches Ravengard. Ravengard nods and steps forward. He holds a sword aloft - the sword of Balduran, perhaps. Gortash kneels, back to player. Everyone takes position for the Archduke ceremony.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Enver Gortash. Swearest thou, by Balduran's blade, to defend the citizens of Baldur's Gate from enemies within and without?
Lord Enver Gortash: I swear.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Swearest thou true faith and fealty to the same, by word, deed, and decree, so that none may suffer?
Lord Enver Gortash: I swear.
NodeContext: Gortadsh is still kneeling looking down.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Gathered guests, grant ye consent?
Player: Stop this. Gortash and Ravengard are with the Absolute!
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A traitor's words - they mean to fracture this Council!
Lord Enver Gortash: Patriars - let it be known. The War of the Absolute has begun.

Nightwarden Minthara: The goblins tell me that you extracted a confession from our prisoner, True Soul.
Nightwarden Minthara: Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Narrator: *Her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul? Little wonder that you serve me so well.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the Absolute's clutches.*
Narrator: *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.*
Narrator: *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*
Player: The tieflings should be warned. Together, you can outnumber her warband.
Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin.
Nightwarden Minthara: Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.*
Narrator: *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Get out of my mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: Destroying this place is the Absolute's will. Would you defy Her?
Player: Open your mind to her.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...*
Narrator: *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect.
Nightwarden Minthara: If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: They'll die thinking I'm their hero.
Nightwarden Minthara: Exquisite. The Absolute chose well when She chose you.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: It shall be so.

Wyll: Counsellor Florrick - are you all right?
Counsellor Florrick: Wyll, by the living gods! I couldn't have asked for a finer saviour.
Counsellor Florrick: A scorched throat, a few hairs singed off. Nothing a bit of time and fresh air can't cure.
Counsellor Florrick: Fist Ito, a new duty calls. Drow have taken Grand Duke Ulder Ravengard - westward, if my eyes and ears can be believed.
Counsellor Florrick: Report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke.
Wyll: No, it can't be. You mean, they've taken -
Counsellor Florrick: Yes, Wyll. The drow have your father.
Player: Ravengard? I know that name.
Counsellor Florrick: As well you should. He is the great champion of the Council, commander of the Flaming Fist - the binding force holding Baldur's Gate together.
Counsellor Florrick: Without him, the city faces collapse. In fact, I fear that may have been the intention of those who abducted him.
Counsellor Florrick: Wyll, you must hold little love for your father. But please, find him and return him to the city.
Wyll: Trust us to see it through, Counsellor.
Counsellor Florrick: May I trust you'll see it through?
Player: You'll have to find somebody else for the job.

Wyll: Counsellor Florrick - are you all right?
Counsellor Florrick: Wyll, by the living gods! I couldn't have asked for a finer saviour.
Narrator: *She is a ghost from your past come to haunt you - Counsellor Florrick, your father's closest confidante, and a loyal servant of Baldur's Gate.*
Counsellor Florrick: It takes more than mere fire to break me, Ito.
Counsellor Florrick: Now listen close, fist: duty calls. Drow have taken Grand Duke Ulder Ravengard - westward, if my eyes and ears can be believed.
Counsellor Florrick: Gauntlet - report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke.
Fist Recruit Aelis: On your command, Counsellor.
Counsellor Florrick: The rest of you - count the dead. Take word of their sacrifice to the city.
Counsellor Florrick: And you - I must ask again for your aid.
Counsellor Florrick: Please - rescue Ravengard from his drow captors. The Council will reward you for your effort.
Counsellor Florrick: May I trust you'll see it through?
Player: You'll have to find somebody else for the job.

Nightwarden Minthara: I have been expecting you. The goblins tell me that you forced a confession from our prisoner.
Nightwarden Minthara: Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.

Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect.

Player: I prefer to face my enemies rather than stabbing them in the back.
Nightwarden Minthara: How noble. I prefer to win.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.

Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: I've done enough. The battle is yours to fight.

Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: If I do this, I expect to be rewarded.

Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: A drow? Tell me, Sazza, did your misadventures take you to the Underdark?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us.
Sazza: This mug helped me escape though. I say we stick a few holes in them... show how grateful we are.

Narrator: *You feel a cold hand caress your mind as the drow appraises you.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Oh dear. Your prisoner is one of the Absolute's favourites, Sazza. A True Soul.
Sazza: Nah. Can't be... they woz in the grove, hangin' around with the tieflin's.
Nightwarden Minthara: Undercover, no doubt. Carrying out the Absolute's will. Oh, Sazza - you have made a grave error.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it will be your last. My spiders are hungry, little one...
Nightwarden Minthara: ...but before they feast, tell me where that grove is, and I may yet spare your life.
Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!
Player: I explained everything to her. She's just too stupid to understand.
Nightwarden Minthara: A liar as well as a fool? I hope you're at least digestible.
Sazza: It ain't true! Them's the bloody liars!
Sazza: Somebody help!
Nightwarden Minthara: Through sheer luck, that pathetic worm has brought me the information I need.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: You have a part to play in this slaughter.
Nightwarden Minthara: Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.*
Narrator: *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.*
Narrator: *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*
Player: I want no part of this.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates and crush our enemies.
Player: All right. Expect me at the grove.

Wyll: Countless souls walk these planes, countless ways to find pleasure. And out of all of them, you chose her.
Wyll: Do you understand what she did - what you did?
Player: Nothing good, from the sounds of it.
Wyll: No, nothing good.
Wyll: For every pleasure you took, a damned soul suffered in the Hells. You fed on the hopeless, the frightened. Souls so desperate, they sold themselves to a devil.
Wyll: Souls like mine.
Player: So? They're already dead. What's a little more torture?

Isobel: On with you. Unless you want to come back to a gaggle of shadow-cursed Harpers.
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*
Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*
Player: Chase away your putrid desires.
Narrator: *As suddenly as it started, you have tamed the Urge. It slumbers again.*
Isobel: There we are. The real you. Your - affliction, is it? - doesn't rule you, does it.
Player: I won't harm you... I don't know what came over me.
Isobel: Why don't we try again, then? Who are you?
Isobel: Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?
Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53]. I mean you no harm.
Isobel: You'd be a bit late to the party if you did. Ketheric Thorm done for. Or didn't you see that angel carving a path straight toward Moonrise Towers?
Player: Forsake your truce. Kill her.

GROUP_SteelWatchers: Stand down, villain. In the name of the Steel Watch.
GROUP_SteelWatchers: Aggressive action will not be tolerated in the presence of the patriars of this proud city.
Player: Point taken. I'll keep things peaceful.
GROUP_SteelWatchers: The Steel Watch appreciate your cooperation, citizen.
NodeContext: Gets new command after starting to engage. Gortash sends a remote command to let the player through.
Lord Enver Gortash: Dearest patriars, but a moment. I must greet a most honoured guest.
NodeContext: Magninamously and a bir formal, but still in the style of a politician where you can't tell if he's being sarcastic
Lord Enver Gortash: Crawling back from their bloody disgrace - it's my favourite assassin! Gods, you're a sight for sore eyes.
Lord Enver Gortash: Orin told me she made a fool of you, but I should've known you wouldn't go down that easy.
Player: You know me?
Lord Enver Gortash: Then she didn't lie - the past is lost to you. Let me clear up some mysteries, then. We share so much history.
Lord Enver Gortash: You and I initiated this plot. We discussed in depth the failures of our predecessors and how to avoid them.
Lord Enver Gortash: We understood that if we were to unite, no one could stand in the way of the Dead Three.
Lord Enver Gortash: So unite we did. First we obtained the crown; then we enslaved the brain. From there, it was but a small step to the most successful religious hoax ever perpetrated.
Player: Ask the Emperor: Is he telling the truth?
GROUP_Emperors: It seems so.
Player: What was my role in this plan?
Lord Enver Gortash: In Bhaal's name, you set your bloody daggers to cause panic in the streets, killing in the Absolute's name.
Lord Enver Gortash: You would have carried out that part of the plan, had Orin not ruined your hard work.
Lord Enver Gortash: Next, the threat of the Absolute's monstrous armies formed by Myrkul's general, Ketheric Thorm.
Lord Enver Gortash: In such circumstances, people crave strong leaders. Leaders that bring law, order, and protection. Leaders like me, Bane's unyielding hand, author of justice.
Lord Enver Gortash: You are soon to witness the people of Baldur's Gate granting me complete power over them. All out of fear of the Absolute.
Lord Enver Gortash: Next, I - we - will declare curfew and begin infecting the masses. Our subjects will hear the voice of their Absolute god.
Lord Enver Gortash: The faithful will do anything in the name of their god.
Player: Very clever.
Lord Enver Gortash: More importantly, just.
Lord Enver Gortash: Now come, be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate.
Player: I have no interest in this sham of a ceremony.
Lord Enver Gortash: Then allow me to pique it for you.
Narrator: *Your brain twists and stretches under the Watcher's gaze. The pain almost brings you to your knees before fading.*
Lord Enver Gortash: You will follow me. And you will show due respect.
Lord Enver Gortash: Distinguished dukes, patriars. Dearest Ravengard - I will heed your call. A new chapter begins.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gortash approaches Ravengard. Ravengard nods and steps forward. He holds a sword aloft - the sword of Balduran, perhaps. Gortash kneels, back to player. Everyone takes position for the Archduke ceremony.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Enver Gortash. Swearest thou, by Balduran's blade, to defend the citizens of Baldur's Gate from enemies within and without?
Lord Enver Gortash: I swear.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Swearest thou true faith and fealty to the same, by word, deed, and decree, so that none may suffer?
Lord Enver Gortash: I swear.
NodeContext: Gortadsh is still kneeling looking down.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Gathered guests, grant ye consent?
Player: Stop this. Gortash and Ravengard are with the Absolute!
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A traitor's words - they mean to fracture this Council!
Lord Enver Gortash: Patriars - let it be known. The War of the Absolute has begun.

Nightwarden Minthara: I trust you have cleared your mind? I hunger for battle. We must find the sanctuary.
Player: Let me see your map. I'll show you where the grove is.
Nightwarden Minthara: So close! Their fate is sealed - and you will be instrumental in the slaughter.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: I prefer to face my enemies rather than stabbing them in the back.
Nightwarden Minthara: How noble. I prefer to win.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: I've done enough. The battle is yours to fight.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: If I do this, I expect to be rewarded.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows whats inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I don't know.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: You learned all this from your studies?
Halsin: Indeed. After we dealt with the drow that ambushed us, Nettie and I were able to inspect the corpse - and the creature that slithered out of it.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: This magic you mentioned - it isn't normal for these parasites?
Player: Then everything we did here was hopeless.
Halsin: Patience. I can't just snap my fingers... but I know where the solution almost certainly lies.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: At least I know what to do now. Thank you.
Halsin: Wait - I could help you find a cure... but I need to settle matters here first.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha was swayed by Shadow Druids. She nearly sealed the grove.
Halsin: Kagha... I should have suspected she'd take things too far. I'll deal with her when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: It's too late to merely kill this horde's leadership - their forces are already marching. If you want me to help, you need to help me first.
Halsin: You must get ahead of them, muster the defences.
Player: You ask too much of me. I can't help you.

Nightwarden Minthara: I have been expecting you. The goblins tell me that you forced a confession from our prisoner.
Nightwarden Minthara: Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Nightwarden Minthara: You serve the Absolute well.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the Absolute's clutches.*
Narrator: *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.*
Narrator: *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Allow her to read your thoughts.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...*
Narrator: *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect.
Nightwarden Minthara: If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: And once I'm inside?
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*

Nightwarden Minthara: I have been expecting you. The goblins tell me that you forced a confession from our prisoner.
Nightwarden Minthara: Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Narrator: *Her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul, jaluk? Perhaps you are worthy to assist me.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the Absolute's clutches.*
Narrator: *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.*
Narrator: *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*
Player: The grove's inhabitants are weak - it's ready to fall.
Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin.
Nightwarden Minthara: Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.*
Narrator: *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Get out of my mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: Destroying this place is the Absolute's will. Would you defy Her?
Player: Open your mind to her.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...*
Narrator: *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect.
Nightwarden Minthara: If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: And once I'm inside?
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: It shall be so.

Nightwarden Minthara: I trust you have cleared your mind? I hunger for battle. We must find the sanctuary.
Player: The prisoner gave up his secrets.
Nightwarden Minthara: Tell me what you know. The Absolute will reward us with such power if we find this place.
Player: Point to the location of the grove on her map.
Nightwarden Minthara: So close! Their fate is sealed - and you will be instrumental in the slaughter.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: They'll die thinking I'm their hero.
Nightwarden Minthara: Exquisite. The Absolute chose well when She chose you.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: Reject these dreams of a bloodbath.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: You're right. I'll see you at the grove.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows whats inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world.
Halsin: It's no coincidence that you found me here, I'll wager? You're after a cure for this parasite.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: You learned all this from your studies?
Halsin: Indeed. After we dealt with the drow that ambushed us, Nettie and I were able to inspect the corpse - and the creature that slithered out of it.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: At least I know what to do now. Thank you.
Halsin: Wait - I could help you find a cure... but I need to settle matters here first.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha was swayed by Shadow Druids. She nearly sealed the grove.
Halsin: Kagha... I should have suspected she'd take things too far. I'll deal with her when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You are aware you're asking me to kill a drow?
Halsin: You drow relish turning on your own, if there's something to be gained. Don't pretend otherwise.
Player: There's no pretence in not wanting to play the assassin. You're on your own.

Novice Grumm: Shit - True Soul Nere's nothing but grub-chow now.
Novice Grumm: Listen up, bastards - I'm taking charge. Clean your 'nads and pack up.
NodeContext: Addressed to the room in general
Novice Grumm: We're marching to Moonrise. And no death-curse'll be stopping us.
NodeContext: Addressed to the room in general
Novice Grumm: Time for the General to recognise us duergar that have been toiling 'round here.
Player: What about the gnomes? What happens to them?
Novice Grumm: What - you'd think I'd just toss 'em? They're coming with me. A gift for the General.
Wyll: Speak up. You can't just let the clan keep them.
Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.*
Narrator: *As the symbol glows, power courses through you. Authority.*
Player: They will make a fine offering.
Novice Grumm: Hells yes. The General can't ignore a haul of fresh slaves.
Wyll: Your heart made of stone? They deserved freedom - and you denied it.
Novice Grumm: Time for the General to recognise us duergar that have been toiling 'round here.
Player: What about the gnomes? What happens to them?
Novice Grumm: What - you'd think I'd just toss 'em? They're coming with me. A gift for the General.
Wyll: Speak up. You can't just let the clan keep them.
Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.*
Narrator: *As the symbol glows, power courses through you. Authority.*
Player: Enter his mind. 'Release the gnomes.'
Novice Grumm: I... I was wrong. I gotta release them.
Narrator: *A shadow swims across your vision, and a familiar voice tells you to be calm. You are loved.*
Novice Grumm: Gnomes - it's your lucky day. Get your squat arses moving, before I take a brand to them.
NodeContext: Addressed to the room in general

Halsin: Then... then it is as you say. They forgot their principles; you had no choice. I will mourn them when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
