NodeContext: pronounced VLAH-kith gawg shkaath ZAI (meaning 'For the honour of Vlaakith!')
Lae'zel: My queen.
Narrator: *The queen who brings conquest to the heavens, sundering planets, destroying the very stars.*
Narrator: *Hot envy swirls within. Your guts will you to author such cosmic tragedies as she has.*
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Player: Stay standing, just as you are.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The Inquisitor frowns at your insolence.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I expected little of istik education, but here we kneel before our queen.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith, unfazed in the least, considers you with critical interest.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face the player at their eye level.
Vlaakith: You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Friend - I came to bring it back to you.
Astarion: You're what? That is the only thing keeping us from a gruesome, tentacled-filled future.
Vlaakith: My child. You walk on the path of ascension.
Vlaakith: Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning.
Vlaakith: The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I shall cleanse it for you, my queen. Tell me how.
InternalNodeContext: He's not altogether sure why this task is falling to the player and not to him, but also doesn't want to challenge his queen's motivations.
Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Find the one inside and destroy them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.

Vlaakith: You are being LIED TO.
Vlaakith: I WILL BE OBEYED!
NodeContext: she loses herself a bit in rage here,
Player: Fine. I will go in and kill them.

Nightwarden Minthara: I will never tire of sitting on dead men's thrones.
Player: And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: So it's personal? Good - let's take her down.
Nightwarden Minthara: You make it sound so simple. She is the Chosen of Bhaal, Lord of Murder, and one of the cult's founders.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What do you remember of your indoctrination?
Nightwarden Minthara: When I first visited Moonrise, I stood before the Absolute in awe.
Nightwarden Minthara: It was more of an idea than an entity. Pure love. Total power.
Nightwarden Minthara: Orin was by my side. She told me that god had chosen me to be a True Soul. Blessed and adored.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: We'll be heroes - the saviours of Baldur's Gate.
Nightwarden Minthara: Let them think that. There is a short path from saviour to ruler - a short and bloody path. I know it well, and we will walk it together.
Nightwarden Minthara: But Baldur's Gate is a mere bauble. We have the chance to seize something much greater. Surely you see it?
Nightwarden Minthara: In killing Ketheric, we fractured the cult's leadership. When we break the other Chosen and claim their Netherstones, we can take control.
Player: A bold gamble. How can you be sure it's possible?
Nightwarden Minthara: I would have thought this entire conspiracy of gods and monsters to be impossible if I had not seen it for myself.
Nightwarden Minthara: We may fail, but we must try.
Nightwarden Minthara: The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: The future you propose is shaped by violence. I'd prefer to find another way.
Nightwarden Minthara: There is violence in your future regardless. With me, you can at least be sure the violence will lead to glory.
Nightwarden Minthara: You are not stupid. When we reach Baldur's Gate and face the other Chosen, you will see that my way is the right one.
Player: Maybe I'll change your mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: The elder brain is the only thing that has ever managed to change my mind. You're welcome to try.
Nightwarden Minthara: We are bound, then, to travel together, even if we do not yet agree on our ultimate purpose.
Nightwarden Minthara: There is yet one thing about you that troubles me, though. Something I need you to explain.
Nightwarden Minthara: When we killed the tieflings, at the grove, I was not in control of my actions. You do not have that excuse. So I ask you - why? Why kill them?
Player: To watch them suffer - I need no other reason than that.

Player: I'd be more impressed if you'd actually killed it.
Arabella: I don't know how. I'd kill 'em all if I could. I - I just want my mum and pops.
Arabella: We followed Zevlor out here. Then he - he -
Arabella: Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran.
Arabella: I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't.
Arabella: Still can't find 'em - but I bet you can. You'll help me, I just know it!
: True
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*
Player: Nature's magic only grows stronger with age, little one. Learn to control it now, while you still can.
Arabella: If I get strong enough, I won't have to run next time... Hmm.
Arabella: Okay. I promise to be really good with practising - but only if you look for my mum and pops. Deal?
Player: Your parents are test-fodder stuffed full of needles, little orphan.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: I'm telling the truth: you don't want to find them.
Arabella: Then what... what is even left for me to do?
Player: People die, and that's that. You can stay in my camp, if you quit your blubbering.
: False
Arabella: To the hells with your camp, and to the hells with you.

Arabella: Hey - I know you! You're -

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The creatures groan menacingly and prepare to lunge
Arabella: Twist'em up!
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella casts her spell. Before the creatures can attack, vines rise from the ground and wrap around them, entangling them to her right
Wyll: Is that... the kid Kagha went after? Seems she's learned a new trick.

Arabella: Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran.

Arabella: Thanks so much. I knew you'd help me again!
Arabella: The vines won't last forever. I don't - I don't s'pose I can stay with you?
NodeContext: Slightly unsure of herself.
Arabella: Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: I was just poking at the rancid dog-meat of your parents' corpses.

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here.
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create.
Balthazar: General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall.
Balthazar: You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: Touch me, and I'll strike you down with all of nature's fang and fury. Go ahead - try me.
Player: You're hiding from shadows - literally. Don't make threats you can't back up.
: True
Balthazar: ...Fine. I'll forgive your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course.
Balthazar: Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work...
Balthazar: Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Nightwarden Minthara: I will never tire of sitting on dead men's thrones.
Player: And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: An old flame?
Nightwarden Minthara: Jealous? You needn't be -  when Orin is in my hands, her agony will nourish me.
Nightwarden Minthara: She is the iblith who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What do you remember of your indoctrination?
Nightwarden Minthara: When I first visited Moonrise, I stood before the Absolute in awe.
Nightwarden Minthara: It was more of an idea than an entity. Pure love. Total power.
Nightwarden Minthara: Orin was by my side. She told me that god had chosen me to be a True Soul. Blessed and adored.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Is vengeance the limit of your ambitions?
Nightwarden Minthara: There is no limit to my ambitions. I will enjoy killing Orin, but unlike her, I do not kill for pleasure alone. I kill to gain advantage.
Nightwarden Minthara: And we have the chance to seize the greatest advantage of all. Surely you see it?
Nightwarden Minthara: In killing Ketheric, we fractured the cult's leadership. When we break the other Chosen and claim their Netherstones, we can take control.
Player: Stealing an entire cult is a new one, even for me.
Nightwarden Minthara: In the long history of these Realms, few people have attempted anything so bold.
Nightwarden Minthara: We may fail, but we must try.
Nightwarden Minthara: The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: The future you propose is shaped by violence. I'd prefer to find another way.
Nightwarden Minthara: There is violence in your future regardless. With me, you can at least be sure the violence will lead to glory.
Nightwarden Minthara: You are not stupid. When we reach Baldur's Gate and face the other Chosen, you will see that my way is the right one.
Player: If you go to Baldur's Gate, you're going alone.
Nightwarden Minthara: Without you - without the Prism - I cannot risk going to the city. The Absolute would take my mind again.
Player: You can stay with me if you swear to follow my lead.
Nightwarden Minthara: Fine. All I ask of you is that you keep an open mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: We are bound, then, to travel together, even if we do not yet agree on our ultimate purpose.
Nightwarden Minthara: There is yet one thing about you that troubles me, though. Something I need you to explain.
Nightwarden Minthara: When we killed the tieflings, at the grove, I was not in control of my actions. You do not have that excuse. So I ask you - why? Why kill them?
Player: To watch them suffer - I need no other reason than that.

Vlaakith: So - it is found.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The planecaster vibrates, shaking the ground around it.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Vlaakith gha'g shkath zai!
NodeContext: pronounced VLAH-kith gawg shkaath ZAI (meaning 'For the honour of Vlaakith!')
Lae'zel: My Queen - shkath zai!
NodeContext: shkaath ZAI - for the honour!
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Lae'zel: The Deathless Queen has spoken. You will obey.
Player: Stay standing, exactly as you are.
Vlaakith: Did your crche teach you nothing?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith, unfazed in the least, motions everyone present to rise.l Everyone rises.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face Lae'zel at their eye level.
Vlaakith: Your choice of allies is most vexing. They do not become you. Lae'zel.
Lae'zel: Ch'mar, zal'a Vlaakith. You know me.
Vlaakith: Urlon of K'liir speaks most highly. As did Al'chaia before him.
Vlaakith: You seek purity. I may yet grant it.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith turns to player and looms over them instead.
Vlaakith: Istik. You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: I am at your command, my Queen. The artefact is yours.
Vlaakith: Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning.
Vlaakith: Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning.
Vlaakith: That 'weapon' you carry - the Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Lae'zel: I will cleanse it for you, my Queen. Tell me how.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Kill them.
Vlaakith: Do this, and I will cleanse you and your allies. Do this -
Vlaakith: - and ascend.
Lae'zel: Ascension? My queen. An honour gained, a burden borne.
Lae'zel: Choose. But know this: the cost of refusal is great.
Vlaakith: Not merely great, Lae'zel. Eternal.
Player: Can't you kill them yourself? I thought 'gods' were all-powerful.
Vlaakith: Perhaps I misheard. You would not speak ill of a god. Would you?
Lae'zel: Do not test her. She will be our ruin.
Player: I spoke too hastily - please forgive me.

Player: I see some familiar faces, but where's everyone else?
Alfira: You don't know? Stars above...
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: I've seen a lot of nasty ambushes in my time - but that sounds among the worst. I'm sorry.
Alfira: It just... it just never stops.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: If he hadn't listened to me, maybe his brother and sister would still be here.
Alfira: Don't say that. When I think of what would have happened if Cal and Lia weren't there...
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Just take it one step at a time.
Alfira: You make it sound so easy - but I'll try.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Cerys: Thought you'd be ten yards tall, the way my people speak of you.
Cerys: Cerys. Scout. Seems we missed one another at the grove, but the others told me how you helped us.
Cerys: A pity. You pulled them from one death-trap only for me to land them in this one.
Player: So you managed to miss all that trouble at the grove. Convenient.
Cerys: I was trying to scout a path for us while you got busy carving one. But don't worry, I've had my fill of fighting since.
Cerys: Aye, and more than half the others with him.
Cerys: We were ambushed out in the cursed lands - cultists of this Absolute. Zevlor froze, begged us to surrender, but...
Cerys: They were toying with us. Making examples. And we'd had enough of taking it.
Cerys: Those of us who cut free just kept running 'til we found this place. The others... maybe the cult got them. Maybe the curse.
Player: You let your fear conquer you. Be careful not to let your life be ruled by it.

Vlaakith: So - it is found.

Astarion: You're what? That is the only thing keeping us from a gruesome, tentacled-filled future.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong.
Vlaakith: Your kind's stoic endurance will be a boon to our cause.
Vlaakith: Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning.
Vlaakith: The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.

Player: It is my greatest honour to obey.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Enlighten me.
Player: Fine, consider your merits acknowledged. Care to enlighten me as to what's going on?
Balthazar: There is a relic here. One which General Thorm desires. No - needs. I will retrieve it for him...
Balthazar: ...and you will help me. Ignorant you may be, you've shown some prowess in scouting and combat by making it this far.
Balthazar: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him might just be the best way to gain access to Moonrise Towers.*
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*

Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?

Zevlor: Your help at the gate was appreciated.
Zevlor: Never thought I'd say this to a drow, but... thank you. I'm Zevlor. And you're...?
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53].
Zevlor: Well met. Though I should warn you - visitors are no longer welcome in this grove.
Zevlor: Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out.
Zevlor: This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Why are they forcing you out?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore.
Zevlor: They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road.
Zevlor: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: I was there, you know. I'd hoped you'd had a happy ending.
Zevlor: We got out alive. That's what matters. And you did too, by the looks of things.
Zevlor: We'll live to tell another tale, if we can just convince these druids not to turn us out on our backsides.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: But big mistakes correct bigger mistakes. Like scribbling your signature in the first place. Silly little mouse.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: But, yes. Hope can help. Your contract is here, in this House - it's...

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Everyone here is mad - even you, especially me - and that makes them dangerous. But it also makes them stupid.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: HE LOVES YOU HE LOVES YOU NOT HE LOVES YOU HE LOVES YOU NOT
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: You're the key to his future kingdom. You're his crowning glory. He has what you need but you are what he needs.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Not a cure, no, not that. But a Hammer to break your chains. Or his chains.
Narrator: *You hear a sound like the rattle of a chain, and an agonising scream in your head as Hope flickers from view momentarily.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Shhhhttttt... Quiet... There it goes...
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Everyone here is mad - even you, especially me - and that makes them dangerous. But it also makes them stupid.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'll make you seem as ruined as the rest of the people here. A simple glamour to make you a terrible wretch.
NodeContext: very enthusiastic, casting a spell to disguise the player
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Now whisper your questions, little wretch. But really quiet, and very clever. Concentrate.
Player: Speak as the words of revenge whispered in a dying sinner's ear.
Player: Focus on speaking as quietly and calmly as possible.
: True
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Remember. Quiet as a mouse.
Player: What Hammer are you talking about?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: THE ONE THAT RAT-A-TATTED THE CHAINS IN PLACE AND BROKE THE FUTURE
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Discovered an ancient gith prince in need of a saviour? The Orphic Hammer is the perfect tool for breaking all infernal chains.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: In the Archive. Down the corridor, past the debtors. OH! The debtors. They won't like you.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: But I like you. I know I do, I think I do, I hope I do. I just need to ask one question, and I'll know for sure.
Player: No. I'm not telling you anything.

Astarion: Morning. I hope last night's little unpleasantness hasn't left a bad taste in your-
Astarion: Well. I hope there are no bad feelings.
Player: Not at all. Having a vampire on our side could be useful.
Astarion: Indeed it could. These are very helpful in a fight.
NodeContext: 'These' referring to his fangs. He smiles widely and gestures to them.
Astarion: Of course, I can't summon wolves or turn to mist like a 'true' vampire. Being a spawn has its drawbacks.
Player: Is that how you can stand in the sun? Because you're not a 'true' vampire?
Astarion: Oh no, I should be cinders in this light. I hadn't seen the sun for two hundred years before we crashed here.
Astarion: Someone - or something - wants me alive. They've changed the rules.
Astarion: Standing in the sun, wading through a river, wandering into homes without an invitation - they're all perfectly mundane activities now.
Astarion: As for my other quirks - well, we can figure those out in time.
Player: If I can help, just ask. We're in this together.
Astarion: Oh you're such a sweetheart.
Astarion: I'm just glad you're being sensible about these revelations. I was worried people might turn up with torches and pitchforks.
Astarion: Although there's still time.
NodeContext: Looks over his shoulder, realising someone's approaching
Shadowheart: A vampire? Well that explains the pallor.
Shadowheart: Given our group's nature, I don't see much harm. We're each monsters in the making, after all.
Gale: A word of warning, Astarion: I taste absolutely awful.
Lae'zel: For his sake, he best not develop an appetite for githyanki.
Player: If you don't like it, you can leave.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create.
Balthazar: General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall.
Balthazar: You and all the rest have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Balthazar: You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: Fine, consider your merits acknowledged. Care to enlighten me as to what's going on?
Balthazar: There is a relic here. One which General Thorm desires. No - needs. I will retrieve it for him...
Balthazar: ...and you will help me. Ignorant you may be, you've shown some prowess in scouting and combat by making it this far.
Balthazar: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: A scout is little good if they don't know what to look for. What does this relic do?
Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
: True
Balthazar: Fine, if it'll spare me your bleating. The relic lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
: True
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...and he will come.
Balthazar: My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Sarevok Anchev: A pleasing thing, to see these stones stained with the blood of she who disgraced my Father.
Sarevok Anchev: A pleasing thing, to see these stones stained with the blood of those who disgraced my Father.
Sarevok Anchev: Our Father.
Sarevok Anchev: I know my like, child of Bhaal - but I needed to see you slaughter, first. To take life and revel in it.
Sarevok Anchev: Are you here to have your vengeance on my granddaughter, Orin?
Sarevok Anchev: But now, you have returned. Tell me, are you here to have your vengeance on my granddaughter?
Player: What do you mean - vengeance?
Sarevok Anchev: It is your right.
Sarevok Anchev: Orin only seeks the Bhaalian favour you were born to inherit.
Sarevok Anchev: She may have usurped you once, but all her rites and rituals will never match her to your natural gift.
Sarevok Anchev: Bhaal is about to name a new Chosen. All is between you and my granddaughter Orin now, and Orin has much to learn.
Sarevok Anchev: Our lord does not care for beauty. Bhaal cares only for death. Death in numbers. Death in droves.
Sarevok Anchev: It is a lesson Orin will only learn in death. I wonder if you will be the one to teach her?
Player: I came here to become an Unholy Assassin, not to clean up after your offspring, Sarevok.
Sarevok Anchev: And yet you share a Father - her relation to you is as strong as it is to me, blood kin. Perhaps stronger.
Sarevok Anchev: I have heard of the duel Orin proposed to you. She seeks to sacrifice you in our Father's temple.
Sarevok Anchev: She dreams that your corpse will be her masterpiece, but she forgets - before your incident, you were the true master.
Sarevok Anchev: You were murder. Pure murder. No excesses. No pretentions.
Sarevok Anchev: I believe you will be the one to slay Orin.
Sarevok Anchev: But you will need my help.
Sarevok Anchev: I see you have not embraced your birthright yet. Perhaps with my stewardship,
Father will bless you yet.
Sarevok Anchev: And when he does, remember grandfather Sarevok. Remember how he helped you. Return to visit him, and tell the blood-drenched tale of your victory.
Sarevok Anchev: Before you may return to our Father's fold, I must first ensure that you remain as pure and worthy of his blessing as you once were.
Sarevok Anchev: So I ask -  why have you brought no offering, child of Bhaal? How am I to lead you in his worship, if you abstain from his most blessed sacrement?
Sarevok Anchev: Come, child of Murder, let me lead you in Bhaal's worship.
Player: Very well, lead on.
Sarevok Anchev: Spirit of the slaughtered - return to us.
Sarevok Anchev: Show us the achievements this child has accomplished in thy unholy name.
Echo of Amelyssan: His will be done.

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: Perhaps not. Patience is important, but cannot impede the other virtues.
Havkelaag: Then we are in accord - the time for action is now.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Sounds pointless. Public opinion will hardly be swayed by such a small experiment.
Havkelaag: Not at first. But if the experiment proves successful, it must be repeated. Only then will we know if the findings are to be trusted.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.

Havkelaag: I say - that wasn't a githyanki egg you were fiddling around with, was it?
Havkelaag: How would you like to sell it to the Society of Brilliance? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: No benefit could justify you inflicting such cruelty.
Havkelaag: Rigorous experimental methods demand we do not indulge our own emotional responses in the application of discomfort to our subjects.
Havkelaag: Only by the full, uninhibited application of psionic stimuli will we have a true measure of whether the child's innate evil has been cured.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.

Quinton: Why?

GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Did you hear about the scarecrow who lost a fight?

NodeContext: Big gestures at the 'wa-hey' (it's his 'signature' sound). Maybe jazz hands or a little dance?

NodeContext: Claps - loudly pleased and encouraging.
Halsin: Oak Father protect you, my friend! You shall weather this trial, I know it!
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Now, I always tell children that they're special. That each and every one of them is unique.
Narrator: *You notice the clown reaching for something behind his back.*
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Tell me - what makes you special?

Player: My courage: I do something even if it scares me.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: Another True Soul was looking for you. Nere - I aided him in the Underdark.
Balthazar: Ah, it was you who pulled his sorry carcass from the rubble. You should have left him there.
Balthazar: The miserable worm tried to kill me, hoping to take all the glory of this mission for himself.
Balthazar: Dull, dull, dull. Nere was never cut out to be a True Soul - he's a very obedient corpse, though.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here.
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Z'rell spoke of a relic - something called the Nightsong in your notes. They were very interesting.
Player: Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: I had Z'rell's permission - that good enough for you?
Balthazar: Z'rell exceeds her authority. But fine, I'll overlook your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course.
Balthazar: Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work...
Balthazar: Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
: True
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...and he will come.
Balthazar: My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Attack.

Wyll: Agh, Hells! I was hoping you wouldn't notice I was gone.
Player: Are you all right?
Wyll: Oh, I'm deeply proud of you. A touch less so of myself.
Wyll: In truth, I don't feel in a festive mood, and didn't want to cast a grey cloud over the night.
Wyll: I'm a devil. I love the people from the grove, but I unsettle them deep down.
Wyll: As I seem to unsettle everyone nowadays.
Wyll: You don't want a devil at your party.
Wyll: Horns this sharp will pop the balloons, you see. And the guests won't take kindly to scars quite so monstrous.

Wyll: Ouch! You don't need to mock me when I'm feeling low.
Wyll: But off with you. This is your day! Have a dance. Enjoy the music.
Player: Can't you tell why I really followed you out here?
Wyll: Clearly Mol has put you up to stealing my britches so you can turn them into a flag for her gang.
Wyll: Not that I'd necessarily object.
Wyll: Too much honey-wine can do that. You should watch yourself.
Player: You're halfway right.
Wyll: Oh! I will safeguard my undergarments with care.
Wyll: Let me think... Why are you really here?
Wyll: Karlach got lusty at the party, didn't she?
Wyll: She's started a huge fire, and you're trying to save my life.
Wyll: Why else? There couldn't be another reason.
Player: Keep trying!
Wyll: It's a long shot, but - maybe you've grown fond of me. Gods know I've grown fond of you.
Player: Maybe just a little.
Wyll: Then we share a similar affliction. For I've grown fond of you too.
Wyll: Though I can't say I've earned the honour.

Wyll: The world spits on those partial to devils. I'm hardly a prime catch.

He Who Was: Where lies your guilt?
NodeContext: Shadar-Kai speaks in a cold, calculated tone.
Madeline: The... Waning Moon...
NodeContext: Speak with dead style
Player: Not many people out here in the darkness.
He Who Was: I am not 'people'. Though many would question how wise it is to approach a stranger in the dark. Be on your way.
Raven: *CAW.*
He Who Was: A fair point - perhaps this one could assist us.
He Who Was: The murdered lie silent. The raven asks - will you be their voice?

Player: It is an honour to meet one of the Raven Queen's scions. What brings you here?
He Who Was: For your kind to know Her ways is rare. You will suit the task at hand well.
He Who Was: This woman tended a bar where she took her patrons, her friends, into her confidence - promised their secrets were safe with her.
He Who Was: Yet she turned their words into knives - and stabbed them in the back.
He Who Was: They died because of her - and to this day her victims lie unavenged.

He Who Was: My reasons are of no consequence.
He Who Was: Your soul sparks with vengeance. With fury. This is your chance to torment a murderer. To make her suffer.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeons voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: Just kill them already - all this torture is pointless.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeons voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: You will stop this sick spectacle at once.
Malus Thorm: Sick. Quite. But on the cusp of a cure:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The goddess has greater plans for me than to submit to your scalpels.
: True
Malus Thorm: Another absence is your fate? But if you are not here to be cured, how will my sisters learn?
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I am but a fumbling squire before a master swordsman. Please, demonstrate so that I might learn.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.

Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?

Balthazar: General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall.
Balthazar: You and all the rest have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeons voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I don't wish to study, only to lift the curse on this land.
Malus Thorm: A curse? Nay, a cure that leads to the very pinnacle of being:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
: True
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: You do me an honour, but I am not worthy. Show me the way of Shar - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Wyll: Agh, Hells! I was hoping you wouldn't notice I was gone.
Player: Are you all right?
Wyll: Oh, I'm deeply proud of you. A touch less so of myself.
Wyll: In truth, I don't feel in a festive mood, and didn't want to cast a grey cloud over the night.
Wyll: I'm a devil. I love the people from the grove, but I unsettle them deep down.
Wyll: As I seem to unsettle everyone nowadays.
Wyll: You don't want a devil at your party.
Wyll: Horns this sharp will pop the balloons, you see. And the guests won't take kindly to scars quite so monstrous.
Player: You just have some fetching horns! I'm envious.
Wyll: Ouch! You don't need to mock me when I'm feeling low.
Wyll: But off with you. This is your day! Have a dance. Enjoy the music.
Player: Can't you tell why I really followed you out here?
Wyll: Clearly to practice your forest tracking.
NodeContext: Jokingly, and trying to avoid talking about what he knows is obvious
Wyll: I love the way your nose wrinkles up when you get the scent of a lead for the first time.
Wyll: Too much honey-wine can do that. You should watch yourself.
Player: You're halfway right.
Wyll: Oh! I will safeguard my undergarments with care.
Wyll: Let me think... Why are you really here?
Wyll: Karlach got lusty at the party, didn't she?
Wyll: She's started a huge fire, and you're trying to save my life.
Wyll: Why else? There couldn't be another reason.
Player: Keep trying!
Wyll: It's a long shot, but - maybe you've grown fond of me. Gods know I've grown fond of you.
Player: Damn right I'm fond of you.
Wyll: Gods know why. You'd be well within your rights to burn me alive.
Wyll: Well, it just so happens I'm fond of you too.
Wyll: Though I can't say I've earned the honour.
Wyll: I mean - the Blade hasn't exactly lived up to his own reputation.
Wyll: The world spits on those partial to devils. I'm hardly a prime catch.
Player: Maybe a kiss would prove my affections.
: True
Wyll: *Sigh.* You drive a hard bargain. But just the one.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player and Wyll stoops to share a quick kiss.
Wyll: I - well, then. Erm, you've got a party to get back to. After all, tonight is about you.

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here.
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Enlighten me.
Player: Fine, consider your merits acknowledged. Care to enlighten me as to what's going on?
Balthazar: There is a relic here. One which General Thorm desires. No - needs. I will retrieve it for him...
Balthazar: ...and you will help me. Ignorant you may be, you've shown some prowess in scouting and combat by making it this far.
Balthazar: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: I'm not the type to make a deal without the details. What exactly am I looking for?
Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
: True
Balthazar: Fine, if it'll spare me your bleating. The relic lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work...
Balthazar: Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
: True
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...and he will come.
Balthazar: My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Attack.

NodeContext: Whispered

NodeContext: Whispered

NodeContext: Whispered

NodeContext: Whispered

NodeContext: Whispered

He Who Was: They died because of her - and to this day her victims lie unavenged.

He Who Was: I seek a record of this one's crimes - written in her own hand.

Player: I will - what must I do?

Vlaakith: Return to the Astral Prism. Slay Orpheus the pretender.

: False

Lae'zel: I have witnessed too much, and you have given me too little. Finally, I can see.
Lae'zel: Orpheus will live, and I will hear his creed. This is my word.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeons voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Precisely.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
: True
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.

Player: In my years of study, I have found no better teacher than example. Perhaps you could volunteer?

Player: Friend - I came to bring it back to you.
Astarion: You're what? That is the only thing keeping us from a gruesome, tentacled-filled future.

Vlaakith: Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning.

Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Find the one inside and destroy them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.

Vlaakith: I WILL BE OBEYED!

Crusher: Think you rule the world, huh?

Crusher: Ya better learn yer place.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeons voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: You will stop this sick spectacle at once.
Malus Thorm: Sick. Quite. But on the cusp of a cure:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
: True
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: In my years of study, I have found no better teacher than example. Perhaps you could volunteer?
: True
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

Narrator: *Behind Ravengard's eyes, something stirs. A spark of life, of self.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: ...help me...
Narrator: *Your tadpole seizes, the Prism stills. Ravengard's empty eyes meet yours.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: As I said. Baldur's Gate will ascend. Toril's first and only Grand City.
Wyll: Father, please. Come back to me.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: Gortash is a tyrant. This 'new dawn' is a lie.

Narrator: *Approaching the cells, you're met by hollow-eyed faces. There's an almost physical stink of decay and neglect.*
Player: Is this how you used to live, Astarion?
Astarion: Hardly. Cazador didn't keep me in luxury, but I've never seen anything like this.
Astarion: They could be sacrifices for the Black Mass, but where did he get them all?
Sebastian: You. I know you.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Astarion frowns and approaches the cell to get a better look at the prisoner who spoke in the previous node. The prisoner steps out of the shadow - he's emaciated, filthy, and dressed in rags that were once finery
Sebastian: You're the one from the tavern. You smiled and joked and got me drunk.
Astarion: You - no. You're dead.
Sebastian: You called me so many sweet things. My name sounded like a lyric on your tongue.
Astarion: Sebastian.
Sebastian: You remember me.
Astarion: You were handsome. Shy. You'd never been kissed.
NodeContext: in shock
Sebastian: You taught me how. And then you destroyed me.
Sebastian: RAGH!
NodeContext: Shout of rage
Astarion: It can't be -
: False
Player: Who is he?
Astarion: It's not just him - I know so many of these faces.
Astarion: They're my conquests. I pursued them, seduced them, then brought them to Cazador. He told us he was feeding on them.
Astarion: But he turned them to spawn. He turned every last one so he'd have souls for this cursed ritual.
Sebastian: How long?
Astarion: What?
Sebastian: How long have I been down here?
NodeContext: rising anger
Player: Stop whining - the only thing that matters is killing Cazador. He's responsible for all of this.
: True
Sebastian: Kill him? That monster?
Sebastian: You can't. It's not possible...
Player: Where is he now?
Sebastian: The grand chamber, just ahead...
Sebastian: But even if you can kill him - what then? What happens to us?
Player: We'll set you free - what else?
Sebastian: Free from this nightmare? It doesn't feel possible...

Player: I see some familiar faces, but where's everyone else?
Alfira: You don't know? Stars above...
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Someone told them to rot in the Nine Hells, that we weren't going anywhere.
Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: I've seen a lot of nasty ambushes in my time - but that sounds among the worst. I'm sorry.
Alfira: It just... it just never stops.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: If he hadn't listened to me, maybe his brother and sister would still be here.
Alfira: Don't say that. When I think of what would have happened if Cal and Lia weren't there...
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Danger is my life - I wouldn't change it for the world.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: Don't worry, I'll find them.

Kar'niss: And you? What are you?

Ptaris: They did not live up to father's code. Even he did not follow it correctly.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?

Ptaris: The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?

Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeons voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I am a scholar, this is true - just not in the study of torture.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
: True
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: 'Only with sacrifice is mastery gained.' For the sisters to learn, you must submit.
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes. Submit I must, into the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

He Who Was: Where lies your guilt?
NodeContext: Shadar-Kai speaks in a cold, calculated tone.
Madeline: The... Waning Moon...
NodeContext: Speak with dead style
Player: You look tough - good. It's more fun that way.
He Who Was: Stay your hand, and be on your way. I'll not raise mine against you.
Raven: *CAW.*
He Who Was: A fair point - perhaps this one could assist us.
He Who Was: The murdered lie silent. The raven asks - will you be their voice?
: False
Narrator: *The raven, the piercings, the general malaise: this is a shadar-kai. Tales and songs featuring servants of the Raven Queen tend to be tragedies.*
Player: Speak plainly - what are you talking about?
He Who Was: Forgive me - it has been some time since I spoke to another.
He Who Was: This woman tended a bar where she took her patrons, her friends, into her confidence - promised their secrets were safe with her.
He Who Was: Yet she turned their words into knives - and stabbed them in the back.
He Who Was: They died because of her - and to this day her victims lie unavenged.
Player: I doubt you're here out of the goodness of your heart.
He Who Was: I have no heart.
He Who Was: I seek a record of this one's crimes - written in her own hand.
He Who Was: Through it, I can summon her spirit - and force her to face trial for her crimes.
Player: Why would you do that?
He Who Was: Your soul sparks with vengeance. With fury. This is your chance to torment a murderer. To make her suffer.
He Who Was: Will you take it?
Player: I will - what must I do?

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here.
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create.
Balthazar: General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall.
Balthazar: You and all the rest have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Balthazar: You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: Touch me, and I'll strike you down with all of nature's fang and fury. Go ahead - try me.
Player: You're hiding from shadows - literally. Don't make threats you can't back up.
: True
Balthazar: ...Fine. I'll forgive your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course.
Balthazar: Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
: True
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...and he will come.
Balthazar: My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Attack.

Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good.
Ptaris: Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: What did they do that was so terrible?

Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
