[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeons voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Loss.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I sought purpose in the natural world - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Player: You must have got clear of the crash site in a hurry.
Karlach: You're lucky I did.
Karlach: The place would have been crawling with cultists if I'd stuck around - and they'd have dragged us all back to Avernus.
Karlach: And I'll be going straight back if those imp-fuckers catch me.
Player: Why were you in hell in the first place?
Karlach: I was a prisoner, forced to fight in the Blood War - the eternal battle between bad and worse.
Karlach: Most souls in Avernus are just meat for the grinder. But not me.
Karlach: I held my own. More than. Turns out I've got a knack for killing demons - and I enjoy it. That made me a valuable asset.
Karlach: Devils don't like to lose their assets.
Player: Judging by the wound, I'm guessing they already found you.
Karlach: Yeah. Not far from here - gang of cultists cornered me in an abandoned tollhouse.
Karlach: I took out a couple, but I need them all dead.
Player: If I do this, what do I get in return?
Karlach: You get a friend who spat in Baphomet's eye and lived to tell the tale.
Player: I'll do it.

Withers: You are indebted to Elminster Aumar. I shall accept coin on his behalf.
Player: Here you are.
Withers: Thou hast my gratitude.
Withers: Now - we must speak.
Withers: Beyond mortal realms, there doth exist an amalgamation of spirits akin to thine own, ensnared by the treacherous cult of the Absolute, felled in its name.
Withers: They bear great discontentment with their destiny.
Withers: For a mere pittance of coin, I might summon the worthiest among them to lend aid to thy undertaking.
Player: I would like to resurrect someone.
Player: I need to resurrect someone.
Withers: Then thou must return with the proper payment.

Withers: She has left this place to hew a new path.

Withers: Hast thou other business?

Gauntlet Edwynna: No refugees. It is decreed.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Halt! By orders of Lord Gortash, refugees are no longer allowed in the city. Turn around.
Player: I have urgent business in the city.
Player: I'm not a refugee.

Gauntlet Edwynna: No refugees. It is decreed.

Player: My name is [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53].
GROUP_SteelWatchers: Well met, citizen.
Narrator: *Your parasite stirs. From the construct, you feel connection. Resonance.*
Player: What in the hells is that thing?
GROUP_SteelWatchers: I am a Steel Watcher, citizen. Here to serve the people of Baldur's Gate in the name of Lord Enver Gortash.
Gauntlet Edwynna: State your business.
Wyll: My good lady. I am Wyll Ravengard. My business is the city's business.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Wyll Ravengard? Of course, of course - the city is always open to you. But I'm afraid you'll still need to comply with new protocol. By Lord Gortash's command.

: True

Narrator: *Behind the Watcher's gaze, a presence awakens. You are seen, you are known.*
Narrator: *Your infernal machinery seems to snap to attention, almost singing in recognition.*
Karlach: Whoa. My engine. It's almost... I don't know. Buzzing. Like it's paying attention.
Narrator: *Your party's prior transgressions are reflected in its stare, as witnessed by the cult's ever-alert scrying eyes.*
Narrator: *It has heard the howls of slaughtered goblins.*
Narrator: *It has seen the deep shadows of Grymforge, and the stone floors left bloodied.*
Narrator: *It knows the cold walls of Moonrise Towers, and the cultists who fell there.*
Narrator: *The Watcher speaks directly into your mind with a voice like poisoned honey.*
GROUP_SteelWatchers: You are marked for special treatment. A defective Steel Watcher. Not simply an enemy of the people, but an enemy of the Absolute. Come quietly, or die.
GROUP_SteelWatchers: You are marked for special treatment. Not simply an enemy of the people, but an enemy of the Absolute. Come quietly, or die.
Player: Consent to arrest.

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: My ardents spoke of one of our kin that escaped a crashing ghaik slave-vessel.
Lae'zel: Ch'r'ai. Vlaakith's justice in flesh.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much, child. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Interesting. My ardents reported that an istik survived the crashed ghaik slave-vessel.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much since. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I heard enough druids died by your hand to make the deity Silvanus himself weep.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I heard there is so much goblin blood on your hands that it soaks their children's nightmares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You also killed Sarth Baretha. She was formidable.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: To business. I suspect you plucked something precious from the ghaik ship. Something that belongs to us.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The weapon. Give it to me.
Narrator: *The artefact stirs in your pocket. Right within your grasp, and desperate not to be relinquished.*
GROUP_Daisy: Don't do it. The weapon is how I protect you.
Lae'zel: Do it. Do not disobey the Inquisitor.
Player: How do you know so much about me?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Some of your species say knowledge is power. They are wrong. Knowledge is everything.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: We took an interest in you when you became involved with this 'Absolute' cult. A pestilence of infected slaves - the first symptom of the Grand Design in action.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: But you are lucky - that weapon you carry is the solution. I have heard it from Queen Vlaakith herself.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Hand it over.
Player: Never.
Lae'zel: Do not try me. Hand over the artefact, or die by my hand.
NodeContext: Threatening and confident. She means what she says.
Player: You can't trust him, Lae'zel. Follow my lead. I will choose the right path.
: True
Lae'zel: Tsk - tsk - tsk'va! I hate that you speak the truth.

Oskar Fevras: Wait, WAIT! I'm just a prisoner - spare me and there'll be coin, I swear it!
NodeContext: Panicked, he just saw us kill a lot of people and thinks we're about to kill him
Player: Who are you?
Oskar Fevras: I'm an artist. These faithless bastards were trying to ransom me back to my patron.
Oskar Fevras: She's a woman of great means - and great generosity to those who serve her well.
Oskar Fevras: Heroes who rescue her prize painter, for example. Oskar Fevras, at your service.
Oskar Fevras: Well, you should at least know what you've paid for. I am the Oskar Fevras, at your service.
Player: I am the [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53], at yours.
Oskar Fevras: A genuine pleasure. I'm in your debt - as is my patron. My betrothed, I should say.
Oskar Fevras: Assuming Lady Jannath still wishes to marry after our little... falling out.
Player: What happened?
Oskar Fevras: She offered me a future, and so in a fit of madness I told her of my past.
Oskar Fevras: Of the woman I'd loved before she found me. Love still, in truth. She was... less than pleased.
Oskar Fevras: I made a timely retreat into the countryside. To paint, and clear my head. To choose, I suppose.
Player: I hope you came to a decision - the paintings are gone.
Oskar Fevras: Wadded up to wipe Zhentish arses, I expect - and good riddance.
Oskar Fevras: Their objective perfection is what caught these bastards' eyes to begin with. Now that I'm free...
Oskar Fevras: Say - I don't suppose you could spare some coin, could you? Ease the discomforts of the road some?
Player: I can spare a little. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows whats inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: Tell me what you've learned about the tadpoles' origins.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: At least I know what to do now. Thank you.
Halsin: Wait - I could help you find a cure... but I need to settle matters here first.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha was swayed by Shadow Druids. She nearly sealed the grove.
Halsin: Kagha... I should have suspected she'd take things too far. I'll deal with her when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: I'll deal with this. You get to safety.
Halsin: I told you, nowhere is safe. Not while this rot festers. Once it is cut out - once the grove is secure - then I shall leave.
Player: Follow me, then. Your bear form may prove useful.
Halsin: Be warned - my presence could make things more difficult... I can only restrain my bear form so much. I won't be able to help but attack goblins.
Halsin: If I join you, we'll likely have to slaughter this entire place. You may want to use discretion when approaching the goblin leaders.
Player: Stay here.

Player: You think a few shadows could beat me?
Alfira: ...Wait. No one's told you?
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Which one was Asharak again?
Alfira: Which...? Back in the grove, he ran drills with the kids. Wooden swords and the like. That seems like a lifetime ago now.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: I know - Rolan isn't happy with me.
Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Only the strong survive. You want to live? Focus on yourself.

Vlaakith: So - it is found.
NodeContext: Vlaakith should sligjhtly overpronounce every word, think Davros from Doctor Who, each syllable drips with a kind of mad, ancient evil
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The planecaster vibrates, shaking the ground around it.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Vlaakith gha'g shkath zai!
NodeContext: pronounced VLAH-kith gawg shkaath ZAI (meaning 'For the honour of Vlaakith!')
Lae'zel: My queen.
Narrator: *The queen who brings conquest to the heavens, sundering planets, destroying the very stars.*
Narrator: *Hot envy swirls within. Your guts will you to author such cosmic tragedies as she has.*
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Player: Wave politely.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player waves politely at Vlaakith.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The Inquisitor frowns at your insolence.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I expected little of istik education, but here we kneel before our queen.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith, unfazed in the least, considers you with critical interest.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face the player at their eye level.
Vlaakith: You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Friend - I came to bring it back to you.
Shadowheart: Fool - that artefact is the only thing keeping us safe. She cannot have it.
Vlaakith: My child. You walk on the path of ascension.
Vlaakith: Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning.
Vlaakith: The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I shall cleanse it for you, my queen. Tell me how.
InternalNodeContext: He's not altogether sure why this task is falling to the player and not to him, but also doesn't want to challenge his queen's motivations.
Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Find the one inside and kill them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.
Vlaakith: You must accept. Refuse, and know my fury.
Player: So the dream visitor is inside the artefact... I can't kill them. They protect me from the Absolute.
Vlaakith: You are being LIED TO.
Vlaakith: I WILL BE OBEYED!
NodeContext: she loses herself a bit in rage here,
Player: No. In fact, maybe I'll free the one inside.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeons voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: You will stop this sick spectacle at once.
Malus Thorm: Sick. Quite. But on the cusp of a cure:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: 'Only with sacrifice is mastery gained.' For the sisters to learn, you must submit.
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes. Submit I must, into the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

Narrator: *The gnomes speak in soft whispers, the words all but lost in the hot air.*
Player: Clear your throat.
Apprentice Laridda: Lunkbug, hush. We're being watched.
Lunkbug: We're working as we can. Very hard indeed.
Apprentice Laridda: Forget the smokepowder - they'd kill Phil on the spot. I won't let you do it.
NodeContext: Whispered
Player: The sergeant's defeated. This is your chance to flee.
Lunkbug: It's my Beldron. He's still back there! I -
Lunkbug: Damn it, Laridda. We've lost enough of us. I'm not losing Beldron, too.
Lunkbug: Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.
Apprentice Laridda: Bug, please. True Soul Nere will - you know what he'll do.
Player: Fear not, gnome. I will protect you. Tell me what you know.
Apprentice Laridda: I - all right. Go ahead, Lunkbug. Tell her.
Lunkbug: A few days back, there was a... a scene. Our friend Philomeen, she's a sapper. Set off a blast and ran off.
Lunkbug: We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map.
Lunkbug: If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Astarion: Well, some explosives would certainly help us free Thulla's friends. They might even survive the blast.
Player: I'll do what I can.

He Who Was: Where lies your guilt?
NodeContext: Shadar-Kai speaks in a cold, calculated tone.
Madeline: The... Waning Moon...
NodeContext: Speak with dead style
Player: Ready yourself for a fight.
He Who Was: Stay your hand, and be on your way. I'll not raise mine against you.
Raven: *CAW.*
He Who Was: A fair point - perhaps this one could assist us.
He Who Was: The murdered lie silent. The raven asks - will you be their voice?
Narrator: *The raven, the piercings, the general malaise: this is a shadar-kai. Tales and songs featuring servants of the Raven Queen tend to be tragedies.*
Player: I will always seek justice for the wronged.
He Who Was: Then you and I were fated to meet.
He Who Was: This woman tended a bar where she took her patrons, her friends, into her confidence - promised their secrets were safe with her.
He Who Was: Yet she turned their words into knives - and stabbed them in the back.
He Who Was: They died because of her - and to this day her victims lie unavenged.
Player: What good is murder if it isn't done in the name of the divine? It would be an honour to punish her.
He Who Was: You see it as I do.
He Who Was: I seek a record of this one's crimes - written in her own hand.
He Who Was: Through it, I can summon her spirit - and force her to face trial for her crimes.
Player: You are not an impartial judge. Why have you decided her guilt already?
He Who Was: My reasons are of no consequence.
He Who Was: Your soul sparks with vengeance. With fury. This is your chance to torment a murderer. To make her suffer.
He Who Was: Will you take it?
Player: I will - what must I do?

Ptaris: You - you don't look like them. You look like me. Who are you?
Player: You've never seen another githyanki before?
Ptaris: I am not a githyanki. Do not call me that!
Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good.
Ptaris: Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: Who was your father?
Ptaris: Havkelaag. He brought me from the shell. Raised me quickly. Taught me to be good. But he failed me.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: I like to think so.
Ptaris: If you only think, then you do not know.
Ptaris: The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: The Ptarian code? Then you follow the teachings of Bahamut?
Ptaris: The purest of your rulers. But you are nothing like him. You are tainted.
Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like his kin's, but their ways are foreign.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: I never should have saved you. But I'm happy to rectify my mistake.
Player: You would have been destroyed if not for me. I saved you.
: True
Ptaris: You were trying to save me? I - I don't understand.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeons voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: You will stop this sick spectacle at once.
Malus Thorm: Sick. Quite. But on the cusp of a cure:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Karlach: What the fuck is this loon talking about.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I sought purpose in the natural world - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Player: Depends. Who murdered this woman?
He Who Was: She is not the victim. Nay, she is the perpetrator.
He Who Was: This woman tended a bar where she took her patrons, her friends, into her confidence - promised their secrets were safe with her.
He Who Was: Yet she turned their words into knives - and stabbed them in the back.
He Who Was: They died because of her - and to this day her victims lie unavenged.
Player: It sounds like she must be punished - thoroughly.
He Who Was: You see it as I do.
He Who Was: I seek a record of this one's crimes - written in her own hand.
He Who Was: Through it, I can summon her spirit - and force her to face trial for her crimes.
Player: You are not an impartial judge. Why have you decided her guilt already?
He Who Was: My reasons are of no consequence.
He Who Was: Your soul sparks with vengeance. With fury. This is your chance to torment a murderer. To make her suffer.
He Who Was: Will you take it?
Player: I will - what must I do?

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeons voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I am a scholar, this is true - just not in the study of torture.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
: True
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeons voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: Just kill them already - all this torture is pointless.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: The sisters require a willing volunteer, a master of the art.
: True
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

Wyll: There will be no great tempest roaring through the skies, no dragon redeemer to save us.
Wyll: What hope, then, for Baldur's Gate? Without the great wyrm's aid, is the city doomed to fall?
GROUP_Emperors: You braved the wyrm's lair, seeking a saviour. Yet it was you - all of you - who vanquished the undead abomination which Ansur became.
GROUP_Emperors: You are more powerful than you understand.
GROUP_Emperors: It is you who are are the tempest. It is you who are the Heart of the Gate.
Karlach: Hate to say it, Wyll - but I agree with the mind flayer. Baldur's Gate doesn't need a dragon - it needs you.
Wyll: You're right.
Wyll: We are the warriors who'll slay the Absolute. We are the guardians who'll defend this fair city.
Player: Nod along silently.
Wyll: The brain will fall - and the people will hail us as champions.
Original lacked determination
Wyll: I could even claim my father's own ducal title and carry his banner after this.
Would be good to feel his ambition and determination here
Wyll: 'Grand Duke Wyll Ravengard.' Marshal of the Flaming Fist, the city's truest defender.
Shadowheart: You might find it an uphill battle to get the city populace to accept a devil as their Duke...
Player: Follow your heart, Wyll. I trust you to make the right decision.
Wyll: I fought to right the wrongs of the Coast, to slay the monsters that hunt the helpless.
Wyll: What good is a champion who puts himself above the people? What good am I as a politician, just out of reach?
Best to redo this just so it flows well from previous line
Wyll: No manner of duke should save a city, only to open a gate to the Hells.
Wyll: There will be no Grand Duke Wyll Ravengard.
Wyll: I am the defender of the weak, I am the stalker of devils -
Wyll: I am the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: Hail the Blade of Frontiers!
Shadowheart: The Blade of Frontiers!
Narrator: *A calm settles over you. The elder brain is a menace - but with the Blade of Frontiers at your side, you know you will triumph.*

Counsellor Florrick: This is far enough - the way should be clear.
Counsellor Florrick: I can't thank you enough. For getting me out of that damned prison. And for giving me courage when I'd all but run out.
Jaheira: Don't be so quick with your gratitude, Counsellor. All we have done is send you back into the battle.
Counsellor Florrick: And reminded me why I fight it in the first place. Truly - thank you.
Player: Your faith in this city is an inspiration.
Counsellor Florrick: A faith passed on by your father. He was ever loyal, even when the skies were darkest.
Player: What will you do now?
Counsellor Florrick: I will travel to the Upper City, find what allies I can.
Counsellor Florrick: You won't fight the coming battle alone. As long as the city stands, I will stand with it. This is my promise.

Wyll: It's funny.
Wyll: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.
Wyll: I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army.
Wyll: But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: How is this a question? The answer is Mizora. It's always been Mizora.
Wyll: So you'd think. But the right answer is much simpler than that:
Wyll: Time.
Wyll: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. My eternal soul is at its mercy.
Wyll: It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods.
Wyll: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.
Wyll: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop time -
Wyll: If just for a moment.
Wyll: Come, let me show you.
Player: All right. But this better be worth it.
Wyll: It is. I promise.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes Wyll's right hand with their left. Wyll smiles and the scene fades out.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright.
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.
Wyll: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.
Wyll: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.
Wyll: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: Enjoy the view. Enjoy Wyll's quiet company.
Wyll: I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before -
Wyll: And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic.
Wyll: If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight:
Wyll: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: Take the acorn and nod.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes the acorn from Wyll's hands. He smiles, but remains kneeling.
Narrator: *Your skin flushes and your soul sings as you palm the acorn. Wishing magic, affection, love - whatever the cause, it's as real as the ground beneath you.*
Wyll: Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after!
Wyll: Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after!
Player: Shit, yes. Let's see the snake this devil's been hiding.

Narrator: *The blessing falls uneasily over your tainted body. You can't help but dream: to kill her would destroy all of Last Light. You yearn for it so deeply...*
Shadowheart: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Perfect.
Isobel: It'll make you immune to the lesser effects of the shadow curse, which will get you closer to the Towers.
Isobel: It won't be enough to protect you against areas of utter darkness, though - where the curse is strongest. This lantern should, though.
Player: I already have a Moonlantern. I can safely travel the shadows.

Isobel: I wish you luck. The very best of it.

Nightwarden Minthara: I do not have time for interruptions from underlings.

NodeContext: unnerved

InternalNodeContext: Cinematic blocked until Orin asset/voice available.
Nightwarden Minthara: A True Soul? Praise be, sister. Are you here to join my hunt?
Nightwarden Minthara: Her heart is more generous than mine. Join my hunt, faerie. And obey me.
Player: I'm on a hunt of my own. I'm looking for a druid named Halsin.
Nightwarden Minthara: Interesting. What do you know of this druid?
Player: I visited his grove.
Nightwarden Minthara: Perfect. This grove is the place I am seeking. Show me where it is, and we will destroy it together.
Nightwarden Minthara: There is a weapon the Absolute seeks - I'm sure those wretches have it hidden away there. We will find it, amongst the dead and the ashes.
Narrator: *Her excitement is palpable. She lingers on thoughts of victory, of unbelievers' blood spilled...*
Narrator: *...and of the weapon. She will seize it, in the Absolute's name.*
Narrator: *You suddenly feel a strange anxiety take hold - not your own, but that of the gith artefact you carry. Somehow, it's afraid...*
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the Absolute's clutches.*
Narrator: *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.*
Narrator: *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*

Narrator: *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Get out of my mind.

Narrator: *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect.
Nightwarden Minthara: If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.

Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*

Wyll: It's funny.
Wyll: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.
Wyll: I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army.
Wyll: But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The archdevil Zariel?
Wyll: So you'd think. But the right answer is much simpler than that:
Wyll: Time.
Wyll: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. My eternal soul is at its mercy.
Wyll: It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods.
Wyll: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.
Wyll: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop time -
Wyll: If just for a moment.
Wyll: Come, let me show you.
Player: Smile and take Wyll's hand.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes Wyll's right hand with their left. Wyll smiles and the scene fades out.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright.
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.
Wyll: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.
Wyll: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.
Wyll: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: Seriously? You dragged me out here to look at a tree?
Wyll: I did. But also to see something else:
Wyll: Me.
Wyll: I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before -
Wyll: And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic.
Wyll: If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight:
Wyll: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: Yes, yes, yes!
Wyll: Gods. You've made me the happiest soul in all the Realms.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes the acorn from Wyll's hands. He smiles, but remains kneeling.
Narrator: *Your skin flushes and your soul sings as you palm the acorn. Wishing magic, affection, love - whatever the cause, it's as real as the ground beneath you.*
Wyll: Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after!
Wyll: Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after!
Player: Join Wyll in the grass. Give yourself to him completely.

She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.

Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: Let's not let an ancient squabble interfere with the task at hand.

Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I'm glad you've remembered who needs whose help here.
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I am already protected. My Lady shields me from the curse.
Isobel: For now, perhaps. But Shar can be fickle, and her love can prove fleeting. Do not turn your back on an advantage you may need... even a Selnite one.
Isobel: If nothing else, it can aid any companions who travel with you - somehow I doubt Shar's largesse was extended to them.
Player: Silently petition Lady Shar for guidance.
Narrator: *She offers you nothing.*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: It won't be enough to protect you against areas of utter darkness, though - where the curse is strongest. This lantern should, though.
Player: Very nice of you, but I've been to Moonrise Towers already.
Isobel: You... have. Forgive me for gilding the lily. I suppose if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing into the night, there's work to be done there yet.
Isobel: I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Glad to see you, friend.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: As you wish.
Player: Florrick is free. She's gathering allies as we speak.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Tremendous news. She proves as loyal to you as she is to me.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I couldn't bear it if she died by my command. May the Triad guide her steps.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: As you wish.
Player: Tell him about your battle with Ansur.
Wyll: I failed, father. The wyrm is fallen.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A terrible fate for Ansur, my son. Yet my hopes for the city's future have never been higher.
Wyll: I don't understand.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You and your allies slayed the undead terror that was once the great Ansur. You are stronger than even the great wyrm.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You will be the one to part the storms and lead the people through. You, not Ansur, are the saviour we need.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: First, you will fell the Absolute. Then, we will rebuild Baldur's Gate, we will take back our city - together.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I will name you Baldur's Gate's newest Grand Duke of the Council. You will be hailed Heart of the Gate.
Wyll: Grand Duke? I look the part of a fiend.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I will tell the citizens and the patriars of your good works. They will know you carry your father's banner.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: But it is true - you are still under the she-devil's thumb...
Narrator: *Uncertainty fills the air. Wyll has reached a fork in his path. In which direction will he travel?*
Player: You are a hero, not an aristocrat. The Blade is a champion. 'Duke Wyll Ravengard' is not.
Wyll: I fought to right the wrongs of the Coast, to slay the men and monsters that hunt the helpless.
Wyll: It is in the wilds that I find my courage, not in the halls of Upper City estates.
Wyll: There will be no Grand Duke Wyll Ravengard. And there will be no Blade of Frontiers.
Wyll: I am now the Blade of Avernus.
Wyll: For as long as demons and devils imperil the Sword Coast, they will be my prey.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Then go with my blessing. Be Faern's great defender.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Courage. Insight. Strategy. Justice. Let these be the lights that guide you, my son. Hail the Blade of Avernus!
Gale: The Blade of Avernus!
Narrator: *A calm settles over you. The elder brain is a menace - but with the Blade of Avernus at your side, you know you can triumph.*

Duke Ulder Ravengard: My own son, still the she-devil's toy. Is this my fate - to be freed from Gortash's hell only to be trapped in yours?
Wyll: It isn't what you think. It never was.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You turned your back on me, on your city, to chase the she-devil and her power. She stinks up this place even now.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: It is exactly what I think.
Player: Wyll's devoted his life to protecting the Coast. He's used his power wisely.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: There is no wise use of the Hells' powers.
Wyll: Father, please - there's something I must show you.
Narrator: *Ravengard's tadpole clenches as your memories - and Wyll's - flow into him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: By Tyr's wounds - I'm in your mind...
Narrator: *The Grand Duke sees Mizora and her infernal sisters. He sees the agony in Wyll's face as an impossible choice is set before him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: No. My son -
Narrator: *The past becomes present, and Wyll's thoughts are laid bare. Ravengard sees Wyll partnering with Mizora to defeat Tiamat's cultists before they could lay siege to Baldur's Gate.*
Narrator: *And he sees everything beyond. The nautiloid journey, the perilous path to Moonrise, the Astral Prism, and the Emperor within.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Wyll.
Wyll: Everything I did, I did for Baldur's Gate. I did for you.
Player: It's the truth, Ravengard. Wyll has always been a faithful defender of Baldur's Gate.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My son, you sold your soul to save Baldur's Gate - and I cast you out for it.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You gave yourself to the Hells' eternal fires so I might walk free.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: By the gods, can you ever forgive me?
Wyll: There's nothing to forgive. You wanted to protect the city. I only ever wanted the same.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You are a better man than most, and a better son than I deserve. I'll yet make amends, but -
Duke Ulder Ravengard: - my duty is first and foremost to the city and its people. There's something I must ask of you.
Player: Go on.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Before I was captured, I was on a mission.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Returning from Elturel, I discovered the plans of the Absolutists. I immediately realised the city couldn't defend itself against such an army.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I didn't despair because the city has a secret guardian, a wyrm that sleeps beneath. He can be called upon in times of great need.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: This is such a time. You've been trained in the ways of the great champions and proven to be one of them. The wyrm will answer your call. You must seek him out.
Player: A wyrm? Are you saying there's a dragon living under the city?
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A bronze dragon, yes. He sleeps beneath us even now, awaiting a hero to rouse him.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The wyrm goes by many names. Ansur. The Waiting Storm. The Heart of the Gate.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: He promised Balduran he'd protect the city if ever its existence was threatened. But just the once.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Since then, the city has faced countless threats, but we always overcame. There was never a need to call on the wyrm - until now.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The Absolute is the greatest threat Baldur's Gate ever faced. The wyrm must be awakened - and the task falls to you.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: There is a tome - 'The Legend of Ansur'. An ancient epic, ill-remembered, dismissed as a mere tale.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I once held a copy, but it was stolen. Find it, let it set the path before you.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Let it set the path before you.
Player: Wyll? What do you make of this?

Wyll: It's funny.
Wyll: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.
Wyll: I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army.
Wyll: But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The archdevil Zariel?
Wyll: So you'd think. But the right answer is much simpler than that:
Wyll: Time.
Wyll: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. My eternal soul is at its mercy.
Wyll: It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods.
Wyll: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.
Wyll: It even comes for your people in the astral sea. Time may hunt slowly - but it still hunts.
Wyll: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop it -
Wyll: If just for a moment.
Wyll: Come, let me show you.
Player: I can't take your hand without hurting you, but I'll follow where you lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright. NOTE: Karlach CANNOT take Wyll's hand, they shouldn't be touching.See N41
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.
Wyll: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.
Wyll: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.
Wyll: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: Seriously? You dragged me out here to look at a tree?
Wyll: I did. But also to see something else:
Wyll: Me.
Wyll: I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before -
Wyll: And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic.
Wyll: If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight:
Wyll: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: Yes, yes, yes!
Wyll: Gods. You've made me the happiest soul in all the Realms.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes the acorn from Wyll's hands. He smiles, but remains kneeling.
Narrator: *Your skin flushes and your soul sings as you palm the acorn. Wishing magic, affection, love - whatever the cause, it's as real as the ground beneath you.*
Wyll: Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after!
Wyll: Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after!
Player: Join Wyll in the grass. Give yourself to him completely.

Wyll: 'The Blade of Avernus.' A new name for a changed man.
Wyll: Ah, but enough reflection for today. I'm of a mind to celebrate.
Player: Eh, I'll leave you to it.

Wyll: I scout both the Hells and the Coast's havens. And I destroy every fiend that dares put its eye on Faern.

Wyll: - and showing them they won't be abandoned.

Wyll: *Sigh* Yes. There is.
Wyll: I will be hunting Mizora.
Wyll: I won't let her claim one more soul, slay one more victim. I'm going to make my way to the Hells and tear the horns right off her damned head.
Player: Let it go, Wyll. There are better ways to help the people of the Sword Coast.
: False
Wyll: I can't let it go.
Wyll: I will return to Avernus. And I'll cut Mizora to ribbons before she can so much as groan Zariel's name.

Wyll: I love the Coast, I love its people. The Blade of Frontiers belongs to them...
Wyll: ... but Wyll Ravengard belongs to you.
Wyll: Faern doesn't need just one hero. It needs two. Say you'll fight with me.
Player: Nothing would make me happier.

Zevlor: You acted quickly. I'm just sorry I didn't get there first.
Zevlor: Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him.
Zevlor: Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor.
Zevlor: And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: What is this place?
Zevlor: A druids' grove, dedicated to the Oak Father, Silvanus. You'll find its keepers just as thorny, I fear.
Zevlor: Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out.
Zevlor: This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: I have no quarrel with druids.
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore.
Zevlor: They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road.
Zevlor: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: Found sanctuary here, did you?
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

Player: If your people survived that, they'll survive anything.
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me.
Zevlor: You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place.
Zevlor: Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I'll see what I can do.
Player: I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Together, Wyll and I will make Baldur's Gate the brightest gem aside the Sword Sea. The Heart of the Gate will prevail.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: As you wish.
Player: Florrick is free. She's gathering allies as we speak.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Tremendous news. She proves as loyal to you as she is to me.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: As you wish.
Player: Tell him about your battle with Ansur.
Wyll: I failed, father. The wyrm is fallen.

Wyll: I don't understand.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You and your allies slayed the undead terror that was once the great Ansur. You are stronger than even the great wyrm.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You will be the one to part the storms and lead the people through. You, not Ansur, are the saviour we need.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: First, you will fell the Absolute. Then, we will rebuild Baldur's Gate, we will take back our city - together.

Wyll: Grand Duke? My soul lies with the city. But...
Duke Ulder Ravengard: But what, Wyll?
Wyll: I have slain monsters, faced illithids, guarded the helpless. To be a duke - is this the destiny I've awaited? Is the nobility my calling?

Wyll: Courage. Insight. Strategy. Justice. These were the lessons my father taught me.
Wyll: Baldur's Gate is my home, and I am its servant. I will be relentless in my pursuit of the greatest good.

Wyll: The Blade of Frontiers is no more. I will be Wyll Ravengard, son of Ulder, proud Duke of Baldur's Gate.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My son! Together, there is no army we cannot conquer and no wrong we cannot right.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Hail Duke Wyll Ravengard!
Karlach: Duke Wyll Ravengard!

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player approaches Wyll. Wyll is practing his dance moves, oblivious to the player's presence, lost in his reverie.
Player: Stay quiet, and watch Wyll dance.
Wyll: Oh! Sorry. I didn't see you standing there. Lost in the steps, truth be told.
Wyll: I need them to be just right. I wouldn't want to fail my new partner.
Player: Keep practising. I'm sure you'll get better... eventually...
Wyll: Maybe. But I'm not so keen to perform solo. A duet's always been more my style. Which is to say -
Wyll: May I have this dance?
Player: Dance? But there's no music.
Wyll: Our hearts can keep time.
Wyll: But I count you as a friend. My closest, in all honesty. Please - dance with me. If we must burn with the Hells' fires, let us burn together.
Player: I'm ready - let's dance.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player smiles and bows, taking Wyll's hand. Wyll turns guiding the player into the the center of the imaginary dance floor he was using to practice at the start of the scene.

Wyll releases the player's hand, and the two assume courtly posture oppsite eachother.

Wyll releases the player's hand, and the two assume courtly posture oppsite eachother.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll stomps, assuming a paso doble stance. Perfect lines. Intense. He takes a few rhythmic steps foward, playfully invading the player's space while maintaining eye contact.
Player: Give a twirl. A calm twirl.
: True
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player does a fun but expertless twirl and smiles at Wyll.
Wyll: How utterly charming!
Player: Take a bow.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player bows and Wyll smiles as he looks on.
Wyll: Now perhaps we might try a more - intimate style.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll begins a slower dance and the player follows suit.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The players come closer together until their lips are a hair away of touching.
Player: Press your lips against Wyll's.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player kisses Wyll, then pulls away.
Wyll: So much shadow around us. To think I almost missed the light.
Wyll: Well - it's getting late. We can't face the morrow if we don't bid farewell to the now.
Player: Move in for another kiss.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player kisses Wyll - he kisses back, then pulls away.
Wyll: *Sigh.* I've drunk wines from Daggerford to Cormyr, but I've never known a taste as rich as yours.
Wyll: Gods damn it. You almost make me forget myself.
Wyll: But I still keep faith in the old tales of love, the once-upon-a-times and the happily-ever-afters.
Wyll: I'd like to do this the proper way. The way of the old romances sung by the bards.
Wyll: Till next time, good night - and dream sweetly.

Mizora: Go on and gloat, bow to your pretend crowd.

Wyll: It's funny.
Wyll: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.
Wyll: I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army.
Wyll: But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: You, yourself?
Wyll: I'd like to think not. The answer is much simpler than that:
Wyll: Time.
Wyll: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. My eternal soul is at its mercy.
Wyll: It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods.
Wyll: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.
Wyll: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop time -
Wyll: If just for a moment.
Wyll: Come, let me show you.
Player: Go on - I'll follow.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright. NOTE: Karlach CANNOT take Wyll's hand, they shouldn't be touching.See N41
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.
Wyll: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.
Wyll: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.
Wyll: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: I'm not sure I can see into forever. But it's still a nice view.
Wyll: My favourite in all of the Coast. All of Faern, even. Not even the Sea of Stars could rival its magnificence -
Wyll: Nor could it rival yours.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic.
Wyll: If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight:
Wyll: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: I can't give you forever, Wyll. But I can give you tonight.
: True
Wyll: But - I can't resist you. I'd sooner know one unforgettable night than a lifetime of 'what ifs'.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll casts aside the acorn and holds his hand to the player.
Player: Join Wyll in the grass. Give yourself to him completely.

Shadowheart: You're here. Just like it told me you'd be, gith.

Shadowheart: It took me so long to find you.

Shadowheart: I can't sleep. The whispering won't let me. It keeps pushing me - to you.
NodeContext: On, " to you" SH's hand drifts toward a knife tucked into her belt at the small her back

Shadowheart: I keep thinking about the knife going deep. It's the only thing they want me to see.
Shadowheart: And I think they'll stop once I deal with you.
Player: You're not dealing with anyone. You're leaving - now.
Shadowheart: No. I'm where I need to be.
Shadowheart: The whispering's already quieter here. Once you're dead, it'll be gone entirely.
Player: Threaten me again, and it'll be the last thing you do.

Shadowheart: What else do I do? My head is splitting open. I can't leave. I can't!

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player walks toward their bedroll/sleeping area.
Narrator: *You are enveloped in myriad sensations, all at once. Flaming desire and icy despair; the strength of iron and the haze of thick swamp mist.*
Mizora: The Nine Hells of Baator. The ultimate torment, some souls would say.
Mizora: Tsk. Those souls lack imagination.
Player: I'm not so sure about this, Mizora.
Mizora: A banquet lies before you. Why should you not gorge?
Player: What exactly will this entail?
Mizora: I'm going to show you the true wages of your sin.
Narrator: *Pure lust courses through your veins and plucks at your flesh. You don't know what you want, only that you want it.*
Mizora: You feel it, don't you? Primal hunger, irrepressible decadence. Forget the heavens - this is paradise.
Mizora: Let me show you.
Player: Sigh and brace yourself.
Mizora: What's the matter. Don't you trust me?
Narrator: *An inferno engulfs you. Your lust blazes hot.*
Mizora: Do you feel it? Avernus. Where Hells' legions march, screaming their rage. Where the Styx collects the blood of the fallen.
Mizora: Where your rightful mistress shoulders the burdens of perpetual war.
Mizora: Reach out. Have a taste.
Player: Take a tentative sip.
Narrator: *A touch of bitter nips at your tongue. It is vile, it is luscious - apples and ashes, fresh honey and bonedust. You ache for another taste.*

JLatino: We have a breath deep construction anim, use that

Mizora: Dis, the blackened elysium. Minauros, the rotting bog. The molten seas and soil of Phlegethos. Stygia, the frozen ocean.
Mizora: Choose a Hell. Have your fill.
Player: The icy seas of Stygia.
Narrator: *You are immersed in a cold ocean blanketed by twilight. Lightning strikes you, energising and illuminating. Now that you know the thrill of its shock, you yearn for more.*

The player extends both arms out toward the flames, palms down. Their eyes close as they connect with Mizora's hellish offerings.

She watches as the pleasure rides out the sensations.

Mizora: One last choice, and starve no longer.
Mizora: Malbolge, the desolation. The forgotten ruins of Maladomini. Cania and its mountains of ice. Or Nessus, the seat of infernal power.

Wyll: I need them to be just right. I wouldn't want to fail my new partner.

Wyll: May I have this dance?

Player: I'm ready - let's dance.

Wyll: Till next time, good night - and dream sweetly.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: You can tell my allegiance from a look?
Isobel: It's an aura. Or a lack of one, really.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I won't be spoken to like that by a Selnite.
Isobel: We've both got a bitter pill to swallow. When this is all over, we can spit it back out.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: Nod. Better to humour her than make an enemy of all in this place. Lady Shar will understand.
Isobel: Refreshingly pragmatic of you. I sense Shar has offered some amount of protection to you already, but... well, no harm in extra precaution - even from a Selnite.
Narrator: *Pain bursts from the wound on your hand. You see yourself kneeling in a dark hall, surrounded by initiates. A female voice preaches against Selne and all she stands for. You nod, rapt.*
InternalNodeContext: Incurable wound imagery/memoriy fragment
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: I don't know what to make of it myself.
Isobel: I suppose Shar is nothing if not mysterious.
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

Mizora: I had no hand in your father's death, Wyll. But that doesn't mean he might not still live.

Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you.
Mizora: Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal.
Mizora: Option two. I break your pact, and you are freed from your duty. Your father dies by his enemy's hand, and Baldur's Gate loses its greatest champion.
Mizora: Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Mizora: Silence, Karlach!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Do the right thing. Give your soul so that your father can live.

Wyll: Holy hells.

Wyll: There will be no great tempest roaring through the skies, no dragon redeemer to save us.

GROUP_Emperors: You braved the wyrm's lair, seeking a saviour. Yet it was you - all of you - who vanquished the undead abomination which Ansur became.
GROUP_Emperors: You are more powerful than you understand.
GROUP_Emperors: It is you who are are the tempest. It is you who are the Heart of the Gate.

Wyll: You're right.
Wyll: We are the warriors who'll slay the Absolute. We are the guardians who'll defend this fair city.

Original lacked determination

Best to redo this just so it flows well from previous line

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: I thought I smelled a Selnite.
Isobel: At your service.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I won't be spoken to like that by a Selnite.
Isobel: We've both got a bitter pill to swallow. When this is all over, we can spit it back out.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Narrator: *Pain bursts from the wound on your hand. You see yourself kneeling in a dark hall, surrounded by initiates. A female voice preaches against Selne and all she stands for. You nod, rapt.*
InternalNodeContext: Incurable wound imagery/memoriy fragment
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we?
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I do, though I already have a Moonlantern.
Player: I already have a Moonlantern. I can safely travel the shadows.
Isobel: Well! Now you have two. Just in case.
Isobel: I wish you luck. The very best of it.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player approaches Wyll. Wyll is practing his dance moves, oblivious to the player's presence, lost in his reverie.
Player: Nice form. Where'd you learn to dance like that?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll does a few more turns and steps, than faces the player and smiles.
Wyll: I've attended my share of fancy balls and masquerades. A few elegant moves can turn all the right heads.
Wyll: Figured it was time to brush up on my skills. I wouldn't want to fail my new partner.
Wyll: I need them to be just right. I wouldn't want to fail my new partner.
Player: A new partner? And who might that be?
Wyll: As luck would have it, they just arrived.
Wyll: May I have this dance?
Player: I'd like to, but I'm afraid I'll trip over my own feet.
Wyll: Don't worry. It's not really about the dance. It's about who's we're dancing with.
Wyll: But I count you as a friend. My closest, in all honesty. Please - dance with me. If we must burn with the Hells' fires, let us burn together.
Player: I'm ready - let's dance.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player smiles and bows, taking Wyll's hand. Wyll turns guiding the player into the the center of the imaginary dance floor he was using to practice at the start of the scene.

Wyll releases the player's hand, and the two assume courtly posture oppsite eachother.
